reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a really good attempt for Square Enix to establish itself on PC gaming ( though I still play it with PS3 controller since it's easier to control, I used a 3rd party controller program to disguise it as 360 controller ).
Graphics : The game's graphic is a little bit on the middle ground for PC ( and especially for SquareEnix ) though the game show much of its details and the true power of SE-animated on the battleground rather than the cutscene ( Maybe my PC sucks but the grame drop during some of the gigantic animation are quite bad ).
Control : The game is console controller friendly and I would suggest you to use one since It's much nicer to get around using controller.
Game's Mechanics : The game use its old and all popular turn base mechanics from the final fantasy series, with a really nice touch here and there. A big improvement though is apart from the main character, anybody else will be treated equally on the battlefield which make the game extremely interesting and fun to play. reviewText:
Very Final Fantasy-esque, but this fantasy setting does tend to get tiring after all these years. The main character is likable enough, but the supporting characters are the ones holding the somewhat flimsy story together.

The controls are definitely made for consoles (I suspect the entire thing is just a weak port, though), so it does take some time getting used to them. Speaking of which, combat is fresh and it gets a bit tactical, but that's only if you can wrap your head around it. It does tend to get very confusing, but once you've gotten the hang of it, it's very rewarding.

All in all, it's a pretty good game, neither groundbreaking nor complete crap. Could it have been better, though? Yes, definitely.

reviewText:
This isn't one of the best games in the world, If you're looking for a good RPG there are several better titles laying around steam. The combat is somewhat fine but seems pretty automatic and easy to deal with if you're a JRPG player. Almost zero grinding (possibly zero if you're not a newcomer to the genre).
The animations are poor. Most characters have nice models but lack expressions and end up doing the same moves over and over. Biggest problem is voice action. Japanese is bearable but english is just terrible making me want to skip every cutscene just so i don't have to deal with those poor dialogues.

I wouldn't recommend this game if you're looking for a immersive RPG with good voice acting, outstanding story and great combat mechanic. Overall it's a 5/10 . Playable but just another RPG with nothing to add but a unique combat mode, not that great to give this game points though.

reviewText: Last Remnant is a JRPG with some good production values and it is worth buying cheap on that count alone. The 'thing' with Last Remnant is the combat system that lets you put up to an army of characters into battle for you. To do this however the game engine has a lot of complexity and much is this is shielded from the player by automation. If you let the automation do everything then you're not involved much and your characters won't improve. However the problems come when you naturally try to understand what's happening and manage the automaton. Unfortunately, it's just difficult to get past the automation and the manual doesn't help you to do it at all. For example there massive amount of detailed itemization in the game and it is important to equip your characters well, however you can't give them items unless they ask for it. They typically won't ask for stuff you want them to have, but if they do they ask for the wrong item, the wrong person asks for it, the same person asks for everything, and even if they take something they might discard it for something worse later. That's just one side of the itemisation problems as well.\n\nSo anyway, there are a lot of good things in just playing Last Remnant but it encourages you look into the complexity and disappoints when it is frequently opaque.

reviewText: TLR is a fantastic game. Sadly the game has an extremely poor reputation from the xbox world where I understand that it is sub par. On the PC however, the game is absolutely beautiful and suprisingly deep. The story won't win any awards for originality I suppose, but personally I really enjoyed it.\nThe main draw of the game however is the turn based combat with a twist. Instead of giving individual party members a command, you assemble small armies and assign them a general strategy to execute over the course of a turn. While this system can seem shallow and perhaps frustrating to those without the patience to learn its intricacies, it is one of the most enjoyable battle sysyems I have ever used in an RPG. Building and customizing each union and your overall team is a lot of fun. If you seek out the sidequests in the game (which easily adds more than 50% more content) you will often find yourself with access to many more allies with which to customize your team.\nIn all honestly if you have no interest in making a decent investment into learning the sysyem then this may not be the game for you. If, on the other hand, you enjoy learning and mastering an intricate combat system, turn based combat, hours and hours of sidequests and a beautiful world to explore, extremely challenging optional bosses, and beautiful looking combat, you will probably love TLR as much as I do.

reviewText:
It's too bad this game came out too soon for the Xbox 360 and ruined its potential. That version was buggy as all get-out and nearly unplayable and, as such, was reviewed with a very strong negative light. This version fixes pretty much every single graphical and technical issue that made that one unplayable and thus is allowed to shine.

I'm mostly a console gamer these days(even though I've been playing PC and Console games both since I was 4 in 1987), so I live for Square Enix games and know their history very well. I worshipped at their feet in the glory days before the merger. They haven't been great since, but for me, The Last Remnant is one of the few standout IPs they've had since they left their old Squaresoft monicre behind them.

This game is equal parts JRPG, strategy, and story-driven RPG. The combat is the main draw and probably the most unique form of turn-based I've seen in many years. Battles take place in a pseudo-strategic form where the player holds many groups of 3+ toons forming smaller parties broken off from the main group of up to 25 party members. You can fight groups of enemies as large as 75+ forming wave after wave and it really lends itself to the whole continental war" vibe that the story tries to evoke. It's something you don't see often
date: if ever and it's very engrossing.\n\nThere is well over 100 hours of content to explore from sidequests to mob hunting to the main story itself and it very rarely gets old. On the pc
recommended: t graphics shine and the art style and creativity of the world is awe-inspiring at times. It is
hoursPlayed: again
voteText: something largely unique in the world of JRPGs. It doesn't feel too much like Final Fantasy
helpfulPercent: but you can see the influence.\n\nOne of the best aspects of this game
votesHelpful: believe it or not
votesTotal: is the music. Take the best soundtracks of the FF franchise and combine it with hard rock compositions by some of Japans best and you have a soundtrack unlike any other out there. I bought the 3+ disc soundtrack I love it so much. It really heightens the impact during combat and brings you in that much more.\n\nAll in all I'd say any lover of JRPGs will love this game. It didn't get it's fair chance because SquEnix botched their chance with the ill-adviced 360 version. Rest assured that this game is 100% playable and will be well worth the cost."

reviewText:
After 190 hours of game time, I just finished my first playthrough of this game.
To be fair I nearly did 100% of its content. But yeah, it has a LOT of content, if you do everything.

So what is this game about? You assemble a team of people, put them together into units (called unions) and do battle in turns. Depending on who you put together into a union the actual commands they get in battle change and depending on which skills your guys/gals use they level different abilities and stats, which in turn affects which classes they will get into. There are also different formations for your unions to use, which affects the stats of the union.

Well, that sure sounds complicated, but rejoice most of this game is easily beatable by just doing whatever sounds good to you.  So you don't have to get into the depth of it if you don't want to, though for me that was part of the fun. It is a really good easy to use but hard to master/really understand type of system.
There are a few optional bosses that are very very hard and beating them may require some kind of special tactics. It feels incredible rewarding when you are finally able to beat them, though.

Does the game have any drawbacks? To be honest the story is kinda eh whatever"
date: but there are tons of optional stuff to distract you from it. The story battles however are pretty awesome. Another negative point is that a few enemies have really really cheap skills
recommended: which can be quite frustrating.\n\nOverall I really liked this game a lot and might even start up a ng+ run of it. Yes
hoursPlayed: that is a recommendation."

Aside from that issue, the game itself is gorgeous, unique and different. If you enjoy immersing yourself in a new world this would be the game for you. reviewText:
Fascinating but deeply flawed, The Last Remnant is an RPG that seems almost intentionally confusing. Every system goes several layers deep and while the depth is interesting, it's a little too complicated for anyone but the most hardcore fans to enjoy.

It wasn't until about 20 hours in that I started to grasp the battle system. Even though I was reading outside information about the game it wasn't as helpful as actually playing the game and after beating the game I'm still not sure about some things. Most people on the internet suggest to keep your battle rating low, but I was constantly running into roadblocks of luck-based fights that were frustrating.

Most of the quests are fine. I liked that they take you directly to the area you need to be almost all the time, but they also make you leave right as you finish the quest as well. This isn't a problem except there are several quests that end with items in the room you finish the quest in, and then it instantly teleports you home. I'd rather talk to someone to port me home so I could get that stuff.

I completed every quest in the game and felt pretty good about the game going up to the last boss. Completing all the quests screwed me, since the final boss was simply too strong for my team and required way too much grinding to get by. Although it's cool that the game changes depending on how you play almost none of it is obvious at any time.

In fact, almost none of the game's systems are surfaced. From some quest parameters to learning skills to equipping friends with items, there is no information at all about the game. The extremely limited tutorial only covers union attacks from different directions. In the Xbox 360 version there are loading screens with tips, but these were taken out of the PC version. Most of the time I resorted to the helpful wiki and an external program that hooks into the game to display things like enemy health and what the heck a class like an Expert Swashbuckler" does.

I found the environments to be boring. So many corridors and caves with few paths that usually just lead to items. A few scenes were pretty
date: but the majority of the game made me feel claustrophobic.\n\nDespite all that
recommended: there's something to this game's battle system that is fun and feels good to play with after learning its intricacies. Breaking this game was a joy
hoursPlayed: learning new spells and training familiar ones is good (though complex) and fighting requires tactics that I rarely see in RPGs. I just wish that stuff was surfaced a lot more in the game.\n\nThere's a reason that this game still has an active community - this game probably has thousands of ways to play it and no two playthroughs will be the same. If you can get past the massive hurdles that are required to play this
voteText: The Last Remnant is a perfectly average RPG that offers a ton of depth in its battle system."

reviewText:
A jrpg with serious grinding and convoluted story problems, but still worth a play.  The main protagonist is horrible and unintelligent and unlikeable, and I'm starting to think that maybe that was intentional?? He's basically jRPG George Bush Jr. as a teenager.

The combat system though is pretty awesome and I wish other games used something like it. A final fantasy 9 remake with this combat system would be the ♥♥♥♥. You have characters and they're put into little squadrons that fight together as a single unit, and how you attack and approach enemies and the angle you use (and subsequently, the ones they use) determine not only your damage bonuses/maluses and the abilities/tricks you can use but also how the morale bar progresses (either towards the enemy side or your side). Understadnably, the morale bar is best on your side, as it has a severe effect on everything.  Its very strateigic and a good play can easily turn the tide of battle in even overwhelming situations.

However, a severe downside is the sheer amount of grinding and gathering you have to do. Dear goodness. You can certainly play through the game without doing any but you'll eventually hit a brick wall of 'this is way too hard even if I play this perfectly' 3/4ths through the game (I did that).  You have to grind this, collect that, grind that, grind this, grind that, so your characters all level up in their weapon and level their weapon up and level what weapons they can craft up and level what weapons their crafted weapons can craft up and level what's availible from shops to aid in crafting that sword to craft an axe to switch over to another skill set and do it all over again for 30+ odd characters.



Nope. Not for me. Maybe for you?

reviewText:
I've been playing for a couple days now with 15 hours of gameplay and my initial opinion of the game is not that great. The world that is presented to you is interesting but many of the characters are incredibly annoying and story telling isn't particularly good either. The main character is a whiney little brat that makes stupid decisions one after another. The game also has a very deep character development system but it is muddled with hidden stats which make it difficult to tell if you're going the right direction.

The combat system has potential to be great but it is very frustrating. Besides the extremely frustrating battle command system, it's not uncommon to run into battles where you can be instantly wiped out without anything you can do to prevent it so saving is your best friend. 1 union vs 5? Yeah, you don't even get the option to heal and round one you die. Boss fight? He's got an aoe attack that can 1 shot your party and uses it every other turn. Without using a guide, figuring out the battle commands is nearly impossible and even using a guide, it is often quite frustrating. Character development is also annoying because there are many hidden stats that are factoring into character class and development. If these stats were visible, it would make the game much better and if you could always tell your units exactly what to do it would make the game immensely better. But that is not the case so it lends itself to an incredibly frustrating learning curve.

If I had paid full price for this I would have returned it in a heartbeat. At $4 I still feel annoyed that I spent the money on it. I feel like this game had a lot of potential that just wasn't capitalized on.

If you do end up giving it a shot, don't grind early on. It only hurts you. And start reading a guide from the start to save yourself a ragequit. If you're not using a controller, in the game settings on the controller page, there is an option to change which buttons the tooltips show (xbox, ps3, keyboard, etc.). Change this to keyboard. And to skip cutscenes, hit Pause/Break and then S to skip.

reviewText:
I wish I could give this game a recommendation.  It's got a solid foundation, with an interesting game mechanic, and it reminds of classic Final Fantasy games.  However, there are really serious flaws that make a possibly great game almost unplayable.  Unless you are a big nerd for JRPGs, stay away.

Some of the flaws are as follows:

1. This is a port of the XBox game.  They didn't even bother to change the quicktime icons that appear during battle, and they don't tell you what they are, either, but they are in the settings.  Still, it's a lazy job of porting it that undercuts the quality of the game significantly.

2.  The battle mechanic is interesting, but ultimately flawed - it's almost like there wasn't enough playtesting.  Skills that target one enemy are the norm, and what the majority of both your characters and enemy characters use.  Unfortunately, the game is quickly dominated by AoE spells capable of killing multiple units.  Characters are organized into groups, which have a shared HP pool, and if they are hit by an AoE spell, it may just hurt one character, or it may hit them all (including characters in other groups).  Because the shared HP is much less than the sum of each character's HP, a group hit usually results in the group being seriously injured or killed in one shot, and too many enemies cast group attacks.  The group attacks should have been seriously nerfed.  On the bright side, you also get these spells - but then the game simply consists of you figuring out which action choice will lead to your character busting out one of these AoE spells and then doing that over and over.

3.  Speaking of action choices: it's only possible to give up to 5 orders (per enemy) - this means that a unit that desperately needs to perform a certain act might not be able to, for reasons that are never clear.  Additionally, you can only ask for certain classes of actions to be performed, rather than specific abilities.  This is kind of neat, as it leaves only the larger tactics to you, but the problem is that the AI is flaky.  Your units will often do stupid things, like target a single unit with a group spell, or just fail to cast a useful spell because the enemy group has been defeated (but the battle is not over).   Also, you may have a TON of AP, but you may only get options to use a few, and so you waste a turn because of the game, not because of some mistake on your part.

Additionally, the plot is some Square Enix gibberish that is completely unengaging.  Square-Enix used to be one of my favorite publishers, and I would really love a good Final Fantasy style game.  If they would stick with the stuff that worked instead of trying to innovate, they could really make some very good games.

reviewText:
This isn't one of the best games in the world, If you're looking for a good RPG there are several better titles laying around steam. The combat is somewhat fine but seems pretty automatic and easy to deal with if you're a JRPG player. Almost zero grinding (possibly zero if you're not a newcomer to the genre).
The animations are poor. Most characters have nice models but lack expressions and end up doing the same moves over and over. Biggest problem is voice action. Japanese is bearable but english is just terrible making me want to skip every cutscene just so i don't have to deal with those poor dialogues.

I wouldn't recommend this game if you're looking for a immersive RPG with good voice acting, outstanding story and great combat mechanic. Overall it's a 5/10 . Playable but just another RPG with nothing to add but a unique combat mode, not that great to give this game points though.

reviewText: Last Remnant is a JRPG with some good production values and it is worth buying cheap on that count alone. The 'thing' with Last Remnant is the combat system that lets you put up to an army of characters into battle for you. To do this however the game engine has a lot of complexity and much is this is shielded from the player by automation. If you let the automation do everything then you're not involved much and your characters won't improve. However the problems come when you naturally try to understand what's happening and manage the automaton. Unfortunately, it's just difficult to get past the automation and the manual doesn't help you to do it at all. For example there massive amount of detailed itemization in the game and it is important to equip your characters well, however you can't give them items unless they ask for it. They typically won't ask for stuff you want them to have, but if they do they ask for the wrong item, the wrong person asks for it, the same person asks for everything, and even if they take something they might discard it for something worse later. That's just one side of the itemisation problems as well.\n\nSo anyway, there are a lot of good things in just playing Last Remnant but it encourages you look into the complexity and disappoints when it is frequently opaque.

reviewText: TLR is a fantastic game. Sadly the game has an extremely poor reputation from the xbox world where I understand that it is sub par. On the PC however, the game is absolutely beautiful and suprisingly deep. The story won't win any awards for originality I suppose, but personally I really enjoyed it.\nThe main draw of the game however is the turn based combat with a twist. Instead of giving individual party members a command, you assemble small armies and assign them a general strategy to execute over the course of a turn. While this system can seem shallow and perhaps frustrating to those without the patience to learn its intricacies, it is one of the most enjoyable battle sysyems I have ever used in an RPG. Building and customizing each union and your overall team is a lot of fun. If you seek out the sidequests in the game (which easily adds more than 50% more content) you will often find yourself with access to many more allies with which to customize your team.\nIn all honestly if you have no interest in making a decent investment into learning the sysyem then this may not be the game for you. If, on the other hand, you enjoy learning and mastering an intricate combat system, turn based combat, hours and hours of sidequests and a beautiful world to explore, extremely challenging optional bosses, and beautiful looking combat, you will probably love TLR as much as I do.

reviewText:
It's too bad this game came out too soon for the Xbox 360 and ruined its potential. That version was buggy as all get-out and nearly unplayable and, as such, was reviewed with a very strong negative light. This version fixes pretty much every single graphical and technical issue that made that one unplayable and thus is allowed to shine.

I'm mostly a console gamer these days(even though I've been playing PC and Console games both since I was 4 in 1987), so I live for Square Enix games and know their history very well. I worshipped at their feet in the glory days before the merger. They haven't been great since, but for me, The Last Remnant is one of the few standout IPs they've had since they left their old Squaresoft monicre behind them.

This game is equal parts JRPG, strategy, and story-driven RPG. The combat is the main draw and probably the most unique form of turn-based I've seen in many years. Battles take place in a pseudo-strategic form where the player holds many groups of 3+ toons forming smaller parties broken off from the main group of up to 25 party members. You can fight groups of enemies as large as 75+ forming wave after wave and it really lends itself to the whole continental war" vibe that the story tries to evoke. It's something you don't see often
date: if ever and it's very engrossing.\n\nThere is well over 100 hours of content to explore from sidequests to mob hunting to the main story itself and it very rarely gets old. On the pc
recommended: t graphics shine and the art style and creativity of the world is awe-inspiring at times. It is
hoursPlayed: again
voteText: something largely unique in the world of JRPGs. It doesn't feel too much like Final Fantasy
helpfulPercent: but you can see the influence.\n\nOne of the best aspects of this game
votesHelpful: believe it or not
votesTotal: is the music. Take the best soundtracks of the FF franchise and combine it with hard rock compositions by some of Japans best and you have a soundtrack unlike any other out there. I bought the 3+ disc soundtrack I love it so much. It really heightens the impact during combat and brings you in that much more.\n\nAll in all I'd say any lover of JRPGs will love this game. It didn't get it's fair chance because SquEnix botched their chance with the ill-adviced 360 version. Rest assured that this game is 100% playable and will be well worth the cost."

reviewText:
Fascinating but deeply flawed, The Last Remnant is an RPG that seems almost intentionally confusing. Every system goes several layers deep and while the depth is interesting, it's a little too complicated for anyone but the most hardcore fans to enjoy.

It wasn't until about 20 hours in that I started to grasp the battle system. Even though I was reading outside information about the game it wasn't as helpful as actually playing the game and after beating the game I'm still not sure about some things. Most people on the internet suggest to keep your battle rating low, but I was constantly running into roadblocks of luck-based fights that were frustrating.

Most of the quests are fine. I liked that they take you directly to the area you need to be almost all the time, but they also make you leave right as you finish the quest as well. This isn't a problem except there are several quests that end with items in the room you finish the quest in, and then it instantly teleports you home. I'd rather talk to someone to port me home so I could get that stuff.

I completed every quest in the game and felt pretty good about the game going up to the last boss. Completing all the quests screwed me, since the final boss was simply too strong for my team and required way too much grinding to get by. Although it's cool that the game changes depending on how you play almost none of it is obvious at any time.

In fact, almost none of the game's systems are surfaced. From some quest parameters to learning skills to equipping friends with items, there is no information at all about the game. The extremely limited tutorial only covers union attacks from different directions. In the Xbox 360 version there are loading screens with tips, but these were taken out of the PC version. Most of the time I resorted to the helpful wiki and an external program that hooks into the game to display things like enemy health and what the heck a class like an Expert Swashbuckler" does.

I found the environments to be boring. So many corridors and caves with few paths that usually just lead to items. A few scenes were pretty
date: but the majority of the game made me feel claustrophobic.\n\nDespite all that
recommended: there's something to this game's battle system that is fun and feels good to play with after learning its intricacies. Breaking this game was a joy
hoursPlayed: learning new spells and training familiar ones is good (though complex) and fighting requires tactics that I rarely see in RPGs. I just wish that stuff was surfaced a lot more in the game.\n\nThere's a reason that this game still has an active community - this game probably has thousands of ways to play it and no two playthroughs will be the same. If you can get past the massive hurdles that are required to play this
voteText: The Last Remnant is a perfectly average RPG that offers a ton of depth in its battle system."

reviewText:
A jrpg with serious grinding and convoluted story problems, but still worth a play.  The main protagonist is horrible and unintelligent and unlikeable, and I'm starting to think that maybe that was intentional?? He's basically jRPG George Bush Jr. as a teenager.

The combat system though is pretty awesome and I wish other games used something like it. A final fantasy 9 remake with this combat system would be the ♥♥♥♥. You have characters and they're put into little squadrons that fight together as a single unit, and how you attack and approach enemies and the angle you use (and subsequently, the ones they use) determine not only your damage bonuses/maluses and the abilities/tricks you can use but also how the morale bar progresses (either towards the enemy side or your side). Understadnably, the morale bar is best on your side, as it has a severe effect on everything.  Its very strateigic and a good play can easily turn the tide of battle in even overwhelming situations.

However, a severe downside is the sheer amount of grinding and gathering you have to do. Dear goodness. You can certainly play through the game without doing any but you'll eventually hit a brick wall of 'this is way too hard even if I play this perfectly' 3/4ths through the game (I did that).  You have to grind this, collect that, grind that, grind this, grind that, so your characters all level up in their weapon and level their weapon up and level what weapons they can craft up and level what weapons their crafted weapons can craft up and level what's availible from shops to aid in crafting that sword to craft an axe to switch over to another skill set and do it all over again for 30+ odd characters.



Nope. Not for me. Maybe for you?

reviewText:
Iniciei este jogo e:

Já sou suspeito pra falar de jRPG, por que são poucos os que eu realmente gosto. Mas esse jogo não tem nada demais. O roteiro é muito pobre, acontece tanta coisa em 5 minutos de jogo, que você acaba se perguntando: Como é que isso está acontecendo? Quem são essas pessoas? Por que elas me ajudam tão fácil? E ainda tem o típico protagonista Japona, simples, tenta ser engraçado, corajoso.

A animação de movimento dos personagens é lamentável. Ver os personagens andando e gesticulando para falar é uma tristeza no jogo.

O sistema de batalha é muito confuso, com muita coisa do tipo faz ai" ou "nem te conto como é que faz". Por que parece que é isso que o jogo te fala. Muita complicação e coisas que acontecem no meio da batalha que você não pode prever e nem se defender.

O sistema de quest é uma vergonha.

NOTA: 4.0 / 10.0"

reviewText:
TLR is a JRPG from Square-Enix with a few flaws and a predictable storyline but is beautifully done.

From the get go, you might have control issues, I did and I had to google how to fix it, but after that it should be a breeze. There isn't a very steep learning curve, but you will most certainly miss things on your first play through than you would if you had known a few things. For example, there's some side missions that unlock certain playable characters that are amazing but they're only open for a limited time, and if you progress in your story you will miss the opportunity to recruit them.

As far as battles go, the fighting is pretty simple, you can set up your characters to form unions (or squads) which pool stats, which I thought was a little disappointing because I really wanted to be able to attack certain characters differently
and position mine differently. Not a bad point, just different from what I'm used to. They have a sort of Limit Break attack move for certain characters like most Square games.

If you do get to check this game out, be sure to play through without a guide first, then check out what you missed, I had a load of fun this way.

Incase you decide to check the guide out first or run through with a guide:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=113566410

In short, I would recommend TLR because it's different but still has a Square uniqueness of fun to it. It has some flaws but the flaws are overlooked by the game's overwhelmingly positive pro's to it's con's.

reviewText: This is a great JRPG coming from Xbox platform to PC. Although its initial release was in 2008, it would still be appealing to newer gamers, especially with enhanced graphics (well, it will also depend on the GPU, though..). A lot of playable characters, equipment and skill customizations, and non-linear quests. If I have to compare it to past Square Enix releases, I will say that the game has its roots in SaGa series (reflected in its customizations and quests), but executed in a different manner. It would be enjoyable to most gamers, especially the ones who like to play JRPG.

reviewText: An often overlooked and underrated attempt to breathe life in to the JRPG genre.  It uses an interesting blend of tactics and traditional JRPG combat in an effort to add something new to a traditionally predictable genre.  I feel it is successful in this endevor, but it ultimately is a JRPG.  If you are tolerant of grinding, repetitiveness and an occasionally obtuse storyline, then you will be able to overlook its largest flaws.  The soundtrack, visuals, and voices (Japanese) are all good, but becoming a bit dated.  Only play this game with an xbox 360 controller.  It's control scheme with a mouse and keyboard are awkward at best.

reviewText:
Pros
+Unique battle system
+Challenging boss fights
+Nice aesthetics as well as graphics
+A lot of side quests which are generally interesting story-wise
+A lot of secrets and extra stuff

Cons
-A few mechanics are not well explained
-Limited autonamy in customizing your party's equipment
-Some grinding required for the best gear


The Last Remnanat is a turn-based strategy RPG with a diferent kind of combat mechanincs. Each character will be placed in a squad of 5 (max) and will act on a general command, such as attack with magical arts, etc. Usually, the available commands are influenced by the abilities of the squad leader and the condition of the battle (if they're dying or if another squad needs help etc.). However, you will not be able to directly control what type of action each individual will perform. For example, the command is to inflict ailments, but you cannot specify whether to silence them, poison them, etc.

However, sometimes characters may change their actions depending on the situation. This is usually due to a successful quick time event (QTE), high morale, etc. Sometimes characters will perform healing abilities because they just need healing, or the command was to offer support to others (not a direct command to heal) or the character's class is just inclined to healing. This makes battles much more dynamic and unpredictable. This all leads up to one thing.

Satisfying boss fights. I can say without a doubt, the best thing about this game is how challenging and enjoyable the fights that matter can be. It's the strong point of the game. Paired with secret and extra bosses that are even more challenging, this is what truly makes the game shine.

Unfortunately, to get there may take some patience as there are mechanics or stats that are not detailed enough, there is no  way to directly give items to your party members, and getting said items may lead into a dull grind. It should also be noted that to be a perfectionist in this game, it will require you to consult the wiki frequently. But then, every good game deserves a wiki, and the Last Remnant is definitely a good game.

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a great JRPG by Square. A unqiue battle system where you take control of a group of soldiers rather than individual units. Hours of quests and exploring. If you like a challenging JRPG this game is for you.

However the mechanics can be a bit confusing at first like the leveling system or lack off. Item crafting is pretty much pointless until the second half of the game as the components are just not easy enough to get until then and I wish they allowed you to equip more items than just weapons and add-ons.

I would suggest looking at gameplay before purchasing as even I was skeptical at first about this game and after playing the Xbox version the PC version is far more superior.

So if your like JRPGs and don't mind devoting hours of your life towards grinding enemies to develop your party. Then The Last Remnant is a game your going to love.

reviewText:
The game has an interesting take on turn-based combat (directing multiple parties of characters that share stats  and move as one unit rather than as individuals); however a lot of the nuances of the mechanics are not well-explained within the game itself. I'd recommend browsing a wiki on basic gameplay to get a better handle on the mechanics the game has.

If you like JRPGs and turn-based games it's worth checking out, imo, though for people who prefer 100% control over every combat decision the variable nature (based on party makeup, party leader, and positioning) of combat commands in battle might be annoying. Basically, most of the strategic thought goes into setting up your parties' characters and their skills beforehand, and then adapting to whatever options you get during the actual combat turns. It may feel a little too random for some people, though you can stack the deck in your favor if you know what you're going for with your group/skill makeup. There are around fifty unique characters that you can choose to recruit into your parties -- some are linked to the main story while others are hidden and can only be obtained after doing certain side quests, as well as 'generic' soldiers that you can hire to pad your army.

The art direction and music are top-notch -- the game looks beautiful on the PC. Areas themselves are linear, though there are many side quests and hidden regions available if you want a break from the main storyline. A lot of the side content can become unavailable permanently if you progress too far in the main story without exploring every area (though there is the benefit of being able to start a New Game + after your first playthrough).
Despite the game's setting being original and interesting, the lead character is a bit of a dope and the main story is not that great, unfortunately (the writing is pretty weak). I honestly enjoyed doing the side content (which includes defeating rare miniboss monsters) more than following the main scenario.

The Last Remnant is unique compared to any other turn-basd RPG I've played, so it's hard to make a blanket statement of recommendation; it really depends on your personal tastes. Basically, your mileage may vary; if you play JRPGs primarily as visual novels and prefer an epic cinematic storyline  with typical gameplay, then this may not be a game for you. But if you are a fan of turn-based combat and are open to investing the time to learn the nuances of this game's unique mechanics (and are a collector and completionist-type), then you might enjoy it.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun, for a guy like me who grew up with a lot of RPGs this is a perfect match.

I really liked the turn based combat, even if you can't choose what spells or abilities to use exactly, it's more like guiding them on what type of abilities to use. I never felt that I lost a battle due to it anyway.

The story is alright, I had some doubts at first but as it developed a bit it drew me back in, and I'd say it's pretty decent. The game also have a pretty good soundtrack to listen to, especially later in the game.

You can expect roughly around 100 hours of fun in this game if you complete most of the side quests, and even more if you decide to upgrade every weapon for your squads.

A very fun and enjoyable game for turn based RPG fans.

reviewText:
Ok, I got this game as a gift from my girlfriend.

I really had a lot of expectations, and added it to my wishlist after having watched a trailer and played a demo on the Xbox 360.

Well... after around 35 hours I started wondering how come enemies were becoming stronger and stronger (e.g. 1 hit kill) even though I had good strategy. Let's break the issues down:

- Fighting/Turn based whatever: this is pretty much random. You can attack an enemy, but even though it's your turn sometimes enemies get more turns than you do, and even take your turn! As soon as you reach a level of 25+ and progress through the storyline, then this becomes a problem since you get your a** kicked REALLY badly.

- Grinding: I wandered around a lot in this game, trying to get more XP in order to unlock some magic, special skill, new areas, collectables, and so on, as it is in any RPG. For example, exploring areas around you and encountering enemies it's always for the sake of a good battle but.... as you read in my first point, I soon realised that this game is not meant for exploration because exploration means fighting (of course, you meet enemies and even if you try to avoid them, you'll probable end up in bloody mess with attacks from everywhere), and it's not about the classic role playing gaming you are used to. This game does not want you to explore or fight - which is the main thing about RPGs - , else you end up with a really high level and you are f***ed as every fight will be a disaster and you'll probably end up using a trainer in order to just finish the game and just delete it forever. Ok, you might say that there is a challenge, however there isn't hardly a challenge here; the game is unfair at all levels, the AI will be just concatenating attacks even if it's your turn, and if you want to have great weapons and hoping" to kick some enemies' a**es

reviewText:
This is a difficult choice, the game has a lovely new and unique battle system that is fun to use and can be customised in great depth. However the story is rather slow and many times I saw myself taking long breaks (weeks or months) away from the game so I could enjoy it.
Another problem is that you have almost no control over a characters growth, it is eaither too easy or too hard, you will be able to swep through areas without much effort, or you will be forced to fight opponents one at a time (which takes ages).
I believe the game is very well made, the story is fresh and new, and very nice to look at.

reviewText:
This JRPG is something I consider and underrated gem.

Story 6/10
The story is generic but not too generic to the point where it's unplayable. It has its moments but is dragged down by its predictability. There is a decent plot twist at the end but it doesn't help rate it any higher. Stories of unique mercenaries you hire are told through their conversations and related missions. Most of them do have an interesting background (Nora, Violet, etc.). But they could have expanded more on their stories which was dissapointing to say the least.

Gameplay 8.5/10
The heart of the game is in the gameplay. You can have up to 18 units in your team, split into a maximum of 5 groups called unions. Each character can learn various skills (with Rush being the only one that can learn every move except for Weapon Specific Arts) and their usage of skills gives them roles the field. However, you can only manually equip Rush with whatever he is able to hold.The others upgrade and request either weapons or components on their own (what they request is based on your Battle Rank and what path you chose for them) The combat system itself is turn based strategy. You have to be smart about what abilities you keep on and what commands you choose. You do not specifically choose what they will do in that turn but you can influence their decisions based on their path and what skills you keep on or off. The combat is very deep and doing a full in-depth review of it would take too long. Try the demo to see if it is your taste.

HOWEVER, I must say that looking at various guides (especially the wiki for the game) is very useful in order to understand the stat gain system and its relationship to the Battle Rank system. You may be familiar with the stat gain system if you have played any of the SaGa RPGs (which makes sense because the developer also worked on the SaGa games as well)

Graphics 7/10
It is the Unrea Engine so the moves look pretty when they're the flashy moves. Sadly, it is also Square Enix's first attempt using the Unreal Engine so there are many texture pop-in issues (but they recover in a few seconds). The environments without Remnants are relatively bland compared to the areas where Remnants are visible.

Music 9/10
The music is great for each scenario. The fights in open areas is very energetic, the fights in closed areas have a feeling of suspense. The music also changes during fights to match the current morale of the team. If it is low, then the music becomes darker, if the morale is high, it makes you feel like kicking ♥♥♥.

Overall, I give it an 8/10

reviewText: A very underrated RPG.  It isn't perfect - its battle system is complicated and there are tons of missable quests and areas - but it's got a lot of high points too.  Here is a JPRG with an 18-character party instead of the usual 3-5.  The enemy encounters are large in scale, and each one will nearly always yield tons of loot, which is used in crafting all manner of items.  The graphics are wonderful with some truly outstanding texture work in places (it uses the Unreal Engine 3), and the score (by Black Mages guitarist Tsuyoshi Sekito) is energetic and memorable.  Also, for those put off by the low reviews of the 360 version, know that the PC version is vastly improved in nearly every way (http://lastremnant.wikia.com/wiki/Difference_between_Xbox360_and_PC_version).  The wiki I just linked to is, by the way, an invaluable resource.  Use it to make sure you don't miss any sidequests, and to understand the game's trickier mechanics.\n\nA complicated, but rewarding, experience.

reviewText: This is a unique JRPG in many ways! The gameplay offers many amazing strategic and personal changes to fit your own style and taste! You create your army in the way you want it to be, hiring on as many of the unit you need or simply taking on the many denizens of the world you've come to aid through your journey! The story has many a wonderful plot twist and the characters develop well over the course of the game! It's one downside is the massive difficulty leap that happens once you max your party slots. The game literally deems you worthy of facing the gates of hell at this point so brace yourself and prepare for some minor grinding! Other than that, the game is a wonderful piece of entertainment with a stelar soundtrack to top it all off~

reviewText:
Overall, Last Remnant is a strong turn-based tactical RPG. The only real flaw I found was the lack of changing tactics on the fly, ie. a group would seek to perform their orders even if it was no longer a valid option for them to do so (out of AP, target group is dead). The game is lengthy, offers a vast choice of party members and compositions, and sports an excellent sound track.

The storyline is nothing special, but it manages to throw a few unexpected hurdles and twists your way, although every attempt at humour is sadly not in the least bit funny.

The main hero is an annoying runt, true to jRPG standards, but at least he can be deposed out of his leadership role to cut down on his voice acting. Other than Rush, the voice acting is pretty good, falling somewhere above your general english localization. Worth picking up.

reviewText:
One of the most underrated JRPGs ever. The battle system has a bit of a learning curve, but is actually pretty great once you get the hang of it. You actually have to think in every battle, since no matter how much you grind (or avoid leveling up), to the very end, you can lose your entire group in one turn in a battle against the weakest enemies in the game.

For those who like to grind and search for hidden stuff, there are plenty of rare monsters to hunt, which can be extremely difficult to find and beat. There are sidequests, some of which are even missable. Some are decent, some are dull fetch quests. All in all, there's a pretty decent amount of content outside of the main quest.

The main storyline is nothing to write home about, and is pretty predictable unless you're new to (J)RPGs, but it's not the worst I've ran into. Recommended to all turn-based rpg fans.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
so far so good.

gameplay-wise i know a lot of people don't like the game as every action you take (or more like influence) in battle shapes the kind of battle style and stats your units will develop. it makes absolutely no indication as to what will change your class (but you can kind of figure melee will get you on the fighter route, magic on the mage route, etc) or how much experience is needed to advance to the next level. lots of people recommend you research which routes you want to take in advanced so you know what actions to choose in game... but i think that's kind of boring/cheaty honestly. i've had no trouble so far and intend to complete the game this way. maybe on new game+.

there's also the issue of battle ranks. battle ranks are this game's way of determining how well you are doing in battle, and are not to be confused with the traditional JRPG's levels. in order to gain stats quicker, you want to keep your battle rank fairly low. basically, in battle you should punish your units and suck as much as you can. this mechanic is definitely interesting but it's pretty damn masochistic.
what i've learnt is to get into battle with multiple semi-tough enemies that will give your units a good wolloping, and just chisel away at their HP in between healing/reviving and if things aren't as going as planned you can do the good old square enix soft reset by pressing all shoulder buttons as well as start/select or in my case back/start. it'll take you back to the title screen so you can load your last save and try again. you should be saving before every battle.

you should also be checking the pubs after every single advancement in the story. there'll be two NPCs standing behind the bar, the one the left is the bartender and the one on the right is the guy/girl you want to be talking to. they'll let you know if there's an available side quest. you should be doing these as soon as you can, and i suggest doing so before continuing with the story as they are constrained to certain plot points. save before you accept any, however, because some of them transport you to new areas that you can't exit unless you finish the quest objective or suspend the quest until later on.

this game was originally released on 360 and ported to pc much later, and because of that, in my medical opinion, this game suffers from mild consolitis.

controls... just use a controller. very bad port in this respect, having to navigate menus with arrow keys and enter is just incredibly lazy and wrong.

it also has major loading times if you have a dual core cpu, which i still do. to fix it, you either need to get the mass affinity.exe to launch the game (mass effect 2 had the same issue) OR do what mass affinity does manually by
going into task manager
right clicking TLR.exe process
set affinity...
then uncheck one of your cores, doesn't matter which.
click apply, then set affinity again
recheck the core you chose, and just leave it like that until you've exited the game.

FOV is also ridiculously small and it's really annoying in wide open areas as you can't see what you're pulling the attention of which is NOT good in this game. if you're willing to, you can change the settings in one of the ini files, and also bind keys that assign different FOV values.

overall there's nothing too much to complain about.

reviewText:
Hobbled on its initial X360 release by dreadful optimisation of the Unreal 3 engine, this PC port of The Last Remnant rights all of its console counterpart's wrongs and lets us actually see the shape of the game underneath.

Which is, for my money, one of the most interesting JRPG titles Square Enix have published in some time. The combat is billed as an RPG/tactics hybrid but it's really more like real-time JRPG combat with a deck-building element. It's something like a more expansive version of Final Fantasy XII's combat, where you control a single party leader while several AI companions make executive decisions based on the orders you issue them. The difference here is that combat has both a 'micro' and a 'macro' component, where both you and the enemy are split up into several parties at once who move about a larger battlefield in turns and mostly engage other parties one-on-one. However, it's also possible to intercept enemy parties (or be intercepted) and to stack multiple parties against one opponent.

It's not the most complex thing going, but it's one of SE's best attempts at marrying traditional JRPG encounter design to real-time combat, far more successful than something like Final Fantasy XIII.

The story and characters are compiled out of mostly-familiar elements, but being freed from the constraints of Final Fantasy formula means that it feels a good deal less creatively exhausted than some of the lesser recent FF titles. As the game progresses you get given far more freedom to recruit more and different soldiers, edit party formations and tactics and generally shape the game's combat. The PC version also has Japanese audio available amongst other reasonably comprehensive config settings.

reviewText:
One of the most underrated JRPGs ever. The battle system has a bit of a learning curve, but is actually pretty great once you get the hang of it. You actually have to think in every battle, since no matter how much you grind (or avoid leveling up), to the very end, you can lose your entire group in one turn in a battle against the weakest enemies in the game.

For those who like to grind and search for hidden stuff, there are plenty of rare monsters to hunt, which can be extremely difficult to find and beat. There are sidequests, some of which are even missable. Some are decent, some are dull fetch quests. All in all, there's a pretty decent amount of content outside of the main quest.

The main storyline is nothing to write home about, and is pretty predictable unless you're new to (J)RPGs, but it's not the worst I've ran into. Recommended to all turn-based rpg fans.

reviewText:
This JRPG is something I consider and underrated gem.

Story 6/10
The story is generic but not too generic to the point where it's unplayable. It has its moments but is dragged down by its predictability. There is a decent plot twist at the end but it doesn't help rate it any higher. Stories of unique mercenaries you hire are told through their conversations and related missions. Most of them do have an interesting background (Nora, Violet, etc.). But they could have expanded more on their stories which was dissapointing to say the least.

Gameplay 8.5/10
The heart of the game is in the gameplay. You can have up to 18 units in your team, split into a maximum of 5 groups called unions. Each character can learn various skills (with Rush being the only one that can learn every move except for Weapon Specific Arts) and their usage of skills gives them roles the field. However, you can only manually equip Rush with whatever he is able to hold.The others upgrade and request either weapons or components on their own (what they request is based on your Battle Rank and what path you chose for them) The combat system itself is turn based strategy. You have to be smart about what abilities you keep on and what commands you choose. You do not specifically choose what they will do in that turn but you can influence their decisions based on their path and what skills you keep on or off. The combat is very deep and doing a full in-depth review of it would take too long. Try the demo to see if it is your taste.

HOWEVER, I must say that looking at various guides (especially the wiki for the game) is very useful in order to understand the stat gain system and its relationship to the Battle Rank system. You may be familiar with the stat gain system if you have played any of the SaGa RPGs (which makes sense because the developer also worked on the SaGa games as well)

Graphics 7/10
It is the Unrea Engine so the moves look pretty when they're the flashy moves. Sadly, it is also Square Enix's first attempt using the Unreal Engine so there are many texture pop-in issues (but they recover in a few seconds). The environments without Remnants are relatively bland compared to the areas where Remnants are visible.

Music 9/10
The music is great for each scenario. The fights in open areas is very energetic, the fights in closed areas have a feeling of suspense. The music also changes during fights to match the current morale of the team. If it is low, then the music becomes darker, if the morale is high, it makes you feel like kicking ♥♥♥.

Overall, I give it an 8/10

reviewText: This is a unique JRPG in many ways! The gameplay offers many amazing strategic and personal changes to fit your own style and taste! You create your army in the way you want it to be, hiring on as many of the unit you need or simply taking on the many denizens of the world you've come to aid through your journey! The story has many a wonderful plot twist and the characters develop well over the course of the game! It's one downside is the massive difficulty leap that happens once you max your party slots. The game literally deems you worthy of facing the gates of hell at this point so brace yourself and prepare for some minor grinding! Other than that, the game is a wonderful piece of entertainment with a stelar soundtrack to top it all off~
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a role playing that has you taking charge of large groups of soldiers as you fight to protect your kingdom from the threat of the Conqueror.

The game is split between a world area, a battle area, and a world map, you control Rush Sykes the protagonist and move him about the world and then use the made too outside of different areas.

In battle you control squads made up of different fighters starting off with being only able to employ a few in each group as you start off you then can build massive armies by the middle of the game mixing in with all sorts of different skills you also gain unique characters too by doing missions or buying them and guilds each one able to be upgraded by finding materials in the area’s you visit

The combat is straight forward selecting from Combat Art (physical attacks) and Mystic Art (magic) mixing these into your group and even having a few groups the specialise in these area are always good. I do find combat can get a little hard but once you figure out which combination of group’s works and what tactics to give them then you’ll have to problems mowing down your enemies

You can also undertake side quests too that help keep a good length in the game and will help you gain more party members and gear.

With the combat being a little confusing and hard it is easy to give up on the game after a couple of loses but if you stick with it this a good game to get through and will leave you some satisfaction once beat those hard boss fights i give this 7 out 10

reviewText: While it might feel odd at first, The Last Remnant provides an interesting twist on Macro-RPG combat mixing the ease of macro-combat, and the complexities of traditional JRPG character growth. The story is decent and combat is refreshing. Performance on the PC is absolutely stellar with neat little tweaks you can make to improve it's fidelity even further.\n\nThe Last Remnant feels like a larger version of Final Fantasy Tactics (the one for the PSX, not the GBA), and helps reinforce the need for careful consideration of chararacter growth and equipment helps to make this little gem a grown up" spiritual successor."

reviewText: In short, this is not a good game. It has many, many problems including an extremely convoluted battle system, a character customization and class system which is hard to manage, a world that doesn't really hold together, obviously half-implemented features, recycled monster types, and a plot that's absurd even for a JRPG. It's hard to play properly, easy to screw yourself over with bad decisions early on, and has a protagonist who's only somewhat more tolerable than Tidus.\n\nThat said: I put nearly 200 hours into this game because it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ addictive to some types of players. It's clear that many of the people who worked on Final Fantasy 12 were instrumental to this game, because the art direction is extremely similar (mostly in a good way although the costumes are even more absurd), it has the same sort of grindy" feel to it
date: and other similarities both obvious and subtle. There are hundreds and hundreds of different components for item creation and customizaton
recommended: a large cast of characters (many of whom have their own optional sub-plots)
hoursPlayed: a guild system with huge amounts of optional tasks
voteText: and possibly most importantly
helpfulPercent: a feeling like you're commanding a small army instead of a fantasy party
votesHelpful: since you have can up to 18 characters active at once in up to five "unions" or tactical squads.\n\nThe PC version has integrated all of the XBox DLC
votesTotal: which includes a bunch of optional superbosses that are pretty much pallette-swaps of existing ones
votesFunny: has more flexible union creation rules (so you can have squads consisting entirely of special characters instead of having to pad them with generic soldier-types)
commentsCount: and possibly most important for the obsessive grinding addicts: a fast-forward mode for finishing battles more quickly. I cannot imagine playing the XBox version without that fast forward.\n\nIf you enjoy farming monsters for that one last rare drop because you just have to get that sword for your tank that's a little bit better than his current one
column16: this is the game for you. If you like your RPGs to have engaging plots

reviewText:
Hobbled on its initial X360 release by dreadful optimisation of the Unreal 3 engine, this PC port of The Last Remnant rights all of its console counterpart's wrongs and lets us actually see the shape of the game underneath.

Which is, for my money, one of the most interesting JRPG titles Square Enix have published in some time. The combat is billed as an RPG/tactics hybrid but it's really more like real-time JRPG combat with a deck-building element. It's something like a more expansive version of Final Fantasy XII's combat, where you control a single party leader while several AI companions make executive decisions based on the orders you issue them. The difference here is that combat has both a 'micro' and a 'macro' component, where both you and the enemy are split up into several parties at once who move about a larger battlefield in turns and mostly engage other parties one-on-one. However, it's also possible to intercept enemy parties (or be intercepted) and to stack multiple parties against one opponent.

It's not the most complex thing going, but it's one of SE's best attempts at marrying traditional JRPG encounter design to real-time combat, far more successful than something like Final Fantasy XIII.

The story and characters are compiled out of mostly-familiar elements, but being freed from the constraints of Final Fantasy formula means that it feels a good deal less creatively exhausted than some of the lesser recent FF titles. As the game progresses you get given far more freedom to recruit more and different soldiers, edit party formations and tactics and generally shape the game's combat. The PC version also has Japanese audio available amongst other reasonably comprehensive config settings.

reviewText: An odd game. Starts off rather cheesy and slow, but quickly becomes what Square is best known for: an engaging and wonderful story with interesting and likeable characters. The combat system is unique and takes some getting used to yet not to difficult to intuit after a few battles, though the RNG nature of it is a little vexing at times. All in all, a solid RPG that stands on its own without needing to be tied to the Final Fantasy name.

reviewText:
While this game can seem cheesy (doesn't even matter whether you've got the audio in English or Japanese), the combat and completionism are more than addicting enough to make up for it.  Once I start playing I just keep going for more combat over and over because it is so engrossing to me.  The music is enjoyable and fitting as well, especially how it changes up through a single combat depending on how you're doing...

Concerning the story....negative: the story is mainly told through hints at it; positive: if you pay attention you can figure out the entire story if you do all the side quests, and it leaves you slightly wistful.

Summary: Do get it for the combat; do get it for the music.  Do NOT get it for the voice acting, and unless you appreciate cheese, do not get it for the story (although I actually like it).

Also, in one respect this game is rather like Ragnarok Online - not in the slightest having to do with gameplay.  There is so much information that if you only have time to play and not to figure out all the mechanics and under-mechanics of how classes work and where items come from, you need the wiki.  Whoever all made the wiki is absolutely insane and worthy of adoration.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. When I first played it, it had the look of Final Fantasy XII (that's the latest game in the series I have played so that's why it's my comparison point) and a fairly good story to match. The combat system at first was appealing. It was different, which I liked. However, as the story progressed and I went further into the game, I started to stop liking it and started to loathe it... and loathe it... and loathe it.

The problems I have with this game are as follows:

1) The combat system. You don't get to fully choose what your unions can do in each turn. You only get to choose from up to five options that the RNG decides what you can choose between (one of which is always the basic attack option). Each set of options changes for each opposing union you can engage so there's a lack of consistency. This means that you will often find situations where you want to heal your units or choose to defend, but only be given the option to attack. When you're being sent into battle against an enemy you know is too strong, you're more than likely going to quit before you get killed.

How they could have done it: Have a standard set of options available to each union for each opposing union. Standard attack, physical arts, mystic arts, healing arts, defend. Additional options can be added in for relevant opponents or scenarios, such as closing in on distant enemies, using item arts or initiating unique attacks such as Omnistrike or the Gae Bolg. Make it consistent and take away the RNG element that makes the system unreliable.

2) The item system. This is just a catastrophic failure in my opinion. It's overly complicated and to this day I still don't understand half of it. My first problem is why can't you change the equipment of any member of your party except Rush? SERIOUSLY! What the hell, Square? Every other game you've done like this allows you to change the gear of other members of your party. Were you trying so hard to not make another Final Fantasy game that you decided none of them needed equipment changes unless the characters just so happen to ask for it? Once again, you put the player at the mercy of the RNG in a part of the game that shouldn't even be random!

Also, why did you feel the need to have every member of Rush's group constantly ask for random items? Why did you have to make the system for giving them better equipment overly complicated? It's unwarranted and infuriating, especially since half of the weapons available from the merchants throughout the game have to be given to other members of the party... but only if they randomly happen to ask for it after you've bought it.

My next problem about the item system relates to the method for upgrading and building weapons and accessories. Why did it have to be so complicated and also not even necessary to proceed with the story? I have not ONCE upgraded any of my weapons nor have I ever created anything new. Reason being, I have never been fortunate enough to possess the very precise consumables needed to do so. Yet, I never felt the need to try to obtain them because the game already provides you with effective pieces of equipment for completing quests or even just exploring areas and finding chests. You added a feature that was confusing and complicated... and then made it completely unnecessary. So my inventory was full of tons of rare enemy drops that I didn't want to sell because I felt I might need them... for no real reason at all.

How they could have done it: Make it possible to change the equipment of your other party members just like in every other game you've made. If you want to have a weapon crafting system, reduce the requirements for creating them and make the item drops rarer and reduce the numbers of items you can obtain. Also, remove the constant nagging requests from every one of your party members asking for items you've never even heard of. It's pointless and wastes time whenever you go to a city map.

3) The Battle Rank system (including quests). Now this has been the one problem I've encountered most in this game. Many of the walkthroughs and forums online say to keep your battle rank as low as possible and to avoid battles as much as you can and then others say to grind and get it nice and high. Honestly, it's overly confusing and I've found that if you don't engage in battles, you get slaughtered. But it's not just ordinary grinding you have to do. It's the quests. Quests in RPGs are necessary for a simple reason. They provide a source of money, items, allies, experience etc. However, they are OPTIONAL, except in this game. In The Last Remnant, if you don't complete the quests, you will be killed when you get to a boss fight. Why that is, I cannot say. I do however know that it's true. I failed to beat many bosses, so I went away to take on some quests, did as many as I could handle before I got bored, went back to the boss and beat them (after a smaller number of attempts).

Not only this, but you are encouraged to take on the quests before a certain point in the game because if you don't, you lose the opportunity to do all of the quests you left behind and any areas you didn't unlock before that point will be lost for the rest of the game. I consider this to be a massive mistake on Square's part. In Final Fantasy VII, you had to change the discs, but you still had access to most of the elements in the game when you changed them. You only lost the chance to unlock a small number of secrets, but the majority of the game was still available to you. So why did they make The Last Remnant in such a different and quite frankly, horrible way? I don't want to feel pressured to complete what I feel are a bunch of tedious and boring quests just to make sure I can progress in the game, especially since all of the quests I have found follow the same format (except one). Get transported to location. traverse location to find boss. Defeat boss. Claim reward. It gets even more boring because of the fact that you keep running into groups of enemies that will run after you and force you to battle if you can't get away.

I'm going off on a tangent here so I'm going to just end this section.

How they could have done it: Make quests optional and replace the battle rank system with an ordinary level system that applies to each individual party member (which would make it easier to form even unions with in my opinion). Also, don't revoke access to areas within the game just because you've reached the middle of the game's story, In addition to that, add in different kinds of quests. They don't all have to end in a boss battle. They can be simpler such as delivering items from one area to another. The quests in Final Fantasy XII were varied enough. Why not here?

4) Battle length. This is one of the reasons quests drag on so much. The battles take so long. The animations are not skippable and you have to watch the entire thing even though you're not doing anything yourself.

How they could have done it: Add an option to skip battle animations and just give the player the outcome of each engagement. Simple.

There are other gripes I have with the way the game was made but I'm going to leave it there for the simple reason that it's long enough already and I doubt that most of you will have even read the entire review. If you did read it all, go have a cookie. You deserve it.

The fact of the matter is, I expected a lot more from Square Enix. They're an incredible group and have produced games for one of the most famous RPG titles for years. Yet, The Last Remnant just fails to live up to the name. Had it not been for the way the world was designed and the unique races that you find in the game, I would never have been able to guess it was a Square Enix title if they took their name off of it. I only managed to make it to the Gates of Hell before I just couldn't take it anymore. GG Square. You beat me.

reviewText:
tl;dr: This game is mostly RNG based despite what it tells you, so if you're fine with relying on luck, then you might enjoy it.
If you like to win through clever tactical decisions or being overleveled and steamrolling enemies; this game has nothing to offer you.


I got this game wanting a chill tactical JRPG where I could grind, explore and craft. After about 50 hours in I feel it delivered on the side quest, exploration and crafting side---

HOWEVER:
The combat is insanely RNG heavy.
You don't have control over possitioning of your party and the game punishes you for bad positioning, you also don't have direct control over what attacks/moves your characters perform. Different moves have different modifiers that are strong against different types of monsters but you don't actually get to choose to use these moves, you just have to hope you get them.  There is also a chance you get a roll in combat where your mages only get to choose between Physical attacks and fighters only get to use Magic attacks. The combat can also otherwise completely screw you over when you get a bad roll out eg: you can end up in situations where you need to/want to heal but the game just doesn't let you because you get bad RNG (this has cost my alot of fights). Even if you get the heal option you only really get one of two options: heal yourself" or "heal someone else" you don't get to choose who that someone else is so you'll just have to cross your fingers and hope.
There is a moral system that supposedly rewards you for making good tactical decisions
date: increasing your damage and defense when you keep moral high. However most of these "decisions" are actually based on RNG and completely outside your control
recommended: and several mobs are immune to it anyway making the combat in general favoured towards enemies
hoursPlayed: especially vs bosses and Rare Enemies.\nThere are no random encounters
voteText: so that's good
helpfulPercent: but there's a system where if an enemy sneaks up on you they get a combat advantage
votesHelpful: however there is no way for you to get an early combat advantage over you enemy via something like a pre-emtive strike.\n\nIf you're the kind of person who likes to spend a lot of time getting good gear for your entire team
votesTotal: this game doesn't allow you to do that either as you only have control of the gear on the main character
votesFunny: while everyone else has their own gear that can only be improved with (say it with me) RNG
commentsCount: as they may ask to have some of the gear you're not using if it's better than what they have. The other way to improve you're allies gear is to gather monster loot where your crew MAY ask to have some of it to improve their gear.\n\nLastly all the enemies in the game scale with your "levels" so grinding isn't all that useful
column16: pretty much taking all the point out of leveling. Further more you can't watch how much XP you gain to see how much more you need to get new moves or what you need for your stats to increase
column17: which is just another annoyance in my already page long complaint."

reviewText:
The Last Remnant.

One of the most underatted games of all time, and one of my favorite rpg's ever.
Originally released on Xbox 360 to mediocre reviews, yet if you played through the
terrible frame rate and texture issues then a true gem was waiting.
On the PC version you can enjoy the game with most of the technical issues resolved.

The battle system in this game is simply amazing, if you truly get into the game and face
some of the later bosses the wealth of depth and tactical choice is awesome. The
fighs are turn based but instaed of controlling individual characters you control different
squads consisting of numerous soldiers recrutted on your journey. As the game progresses
the squad limit rises with your level (Battle Rank) which means battles get bigger and better
the further you get. This leads to some epic, amazing and huge encounters.

The progression, story and side quests all fit into one of square enix's darker tales. While the
story isn't the greatest I've experienced in  a JRPG it's still very good. I love the lore and history
of the game world. If you want to do all of the side quests there is well over 100 hrs of gameplay
(I must have at least 500 hrs on Xbox). It starts slow but stay with it.

To put into perspective how highly I rate this game here is my top 5 JRPG's (in no order 'top 5' was hard enough)
The Last Remnant
Dagon Quest - The Journey of the Cursed King (say no more)
Final Fantasy XII (yes 12, a masterpiece and way ahead of it's time in my humble opinion)
Grandia (my word what a game)
Persona 4 (sweeeeeet)

As you can see it joins some pretty good games on that list.
Word of advise if you are just starting the game- grind for an hour or so early on or the first true boss will
own you.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
I personally did not enjoy The Last Remnant very much, but for $10, it is still a lot of bang for your buck.  The combat was a little unwieldy, and the movement was jerky.  I found the controller support rather nice, though!  And that music is just beautiful.  I love the sound effects, as well.  Everything audio-related is nice except the pauses between voice-overs and the lack of lip sync.

If you are already a fan of similar games, this may be a nice bargain bin game for you.  If you liked .Hack//Infection, you will probably like how Last Remnant feels similar in regard to shops and the exploration of sectioned-off maps.  If you liked The Legend Of Dragoon, the battle system in The Last Remnant is similar though a lot more simplified and not quite as fun in my opinion.  The movement between sections of the world requires use of a boring map menu system that ruins the immersion and ruins any chance of the game offering exploratory experiences.

Again, the game offers a lot of content and is a good buy if you want a time-waster, but keep your expectations low in regards to movement, dialogue, story, and looting.
