reviewText:
Recommended BUT....

This game is an odd one.  It's a JRPG complete with animal people, teenaged leading character, and a fairly good story once it gets started but it's got a pretty strange combat system.  It supports mouse/keyboard though it could have supported them better.  It also has a tendency to hide pretty important information on how the game works but there's now an excellent Wikia website that will fill you in on all the details you care to learn.

The combat system is really the make-or-break feature for this game, IMHO, and it's very different from anything I've ever played before or since.  It's turn based but you get to have a lot of characters in your party (up to 18 eventually) so telling each one of them exactly what to would take way too long.  Instead, you divide your team into squads then give general orders to the squad along the lines of attack with melee" and "stand back and heal" then the members of the squad use their abilities to carry out those orders.

Not all the possible commands appear every round
date: though.  The game will pick out four or five of them depending on the situation
hoursPlayed: and other factors.  That will drive some folks crazy but I found it to be a fun part of the game as it forced me to think about what I could still do even though I didn't get to do exactly what I wanted.  It's a bit like being dealt a hand of cards then figuring out what to do with them instead of picking out the best cards from the deck every time.\n\nYou're definitely given a lot of choices in this game.  Simply picking the most expensive commands and attacking whatever is right in front of you with whatever squads you throw together will work OK for a few hours but you'll never make it through the whole game that way.  You're going to need to think about what characters should make up your squads
voteText: how many squads you should have
helpfulPercent: which characters should lead
votesHelpful: which characters to hire
votesTotal: which monsters to attack (genocide is NOT the answer)
votesFunny: how many to attack at once
commentsCount: whether to send all your squads after one enemy squad or to spread out more
column16: and so on.  You certainly don't need to master every aspect of the game to complete it but you do need to get good at most of them.  (Unfortunately
column17: the game doesn't have a difficulty setting.)\n\nCharacter skill progression is a learn-by-doing system.  If you want Nora casting Cachexia by the end of the game then you'll need to let her do some poison gas spells instead of pounding everything with her hammer.  Character weapons are a major part of progression
column18: too
column19: which are advanced by finding components for your characters to use.  (The Wikia site is extremely handy for that aspect of the game.  Why the developers thought you would actually remember where you found some necrotic metal or which type of critter dropped a mystic fiend horn I have no idea.)\n\nI see a lot of reviews are complaining about grinding... uhh
column20: yeah
column21: you can ignore those.  This is one of the few JRPGs that will actually PUNISH you if you try to exploit the game by grinding!  You see
column22: most JRPGs have fixed monster levels while the characters that get added to your party as you find them automatically adjust to the player's level.  So some people will sit back in the early parts of the game fighting the same monsters over and over until they are so high level that nothing can stop them.  In this game
column23: the characters you find are fixed level but several of the monsters scale to your party's level.  That means the same tactic in this game will result in hiring weak characters against enemies that only a few members in your party can really fight!\n\nThat said
column24: the game CAN turn grindy after you've gotten all the characters you want but it's completely optional.  The game can be completed just fine with no grinding at all.  You won't be able to finish some of the most difficult quests but you won't miss out on any of the story at all."

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a great JRPG, and while the Xbox version had some issues, they all seem to have been resolved in the PC version. Battle Rank (a leveling system that scales up enemy strength the higher your Battle Rank is) is a bit more balanced than it was in the Xbox version, so the penalty for grinding isn't as great. The framerate has been greatly improved, and you are now able to make unions entirely out of general units instead of having to hire the free generic soldiers to fill in gaps, which makes the game much more fun and interesting.

The story is well written overall, though I wouldn't say that it's the best point of the game. It's interesting, but what really makes the game shine is the combat and the sidequests. There are tons of sidequests to complete and guilds to visit all across the world and the rewards are all genearlly very useful and valuable, ranging from general units to recruit to components to unique weapons. The battle system itself may seem really confusing and complex at first, and then it may seem a bit basic and boring once you get through the first scene, but very quickly it expands and becomes much more exciting and interesting. It is honestly one of my favorite battle systems out of any RPG that I've played.

I'd definitely reccomend this game to anyone who is a fan of JRPGs and intricate battle systems. The game is a blast to play, it has a great soundtrack, and the atmosphere and visuals are amazing.

reviewText:
First off, be warned: this game is LONG.  I did most of the sidequests and a good number of the guild tasks, and I felt like I was playing forever.  However, that's not necessarily a bad thing (after all, I played Skyrim for the better part of a year...).  Overall, the game is very well-done - interesting plot & characters, decent pacing, beautiful graphics and world design, and an unusual battle system.

There are a few downsides:
- I felt like the main character is super annoying.  He's probably supposed to come off as immature, but at times I think they really overdid it.
- The plot left a lot of unanswered questions, chief among them what the Remnants are and where they came from.
- Some of the maps are HUGE, and the party's movement speed is just a jog.  So some of the sidequests or even just exploring seems like plain old padding at times.
- It's kinda annoying that the game has no vsync, so unless you can fix it with your graphics driver, you'll have to get used to lots of tearing.
- Unless there's something I missed, it looks like you should have 25 slots for active party members, but the most I ever unlocked was 18.  Of course, those 18 were more than enough to make the final battle a curb-stomp.
- I never quite figured out the formations, especially the more powerful" versions you get as the game goes on.  My squads were just fine mostly sticking with the early-game formations right up until the end.

I mentioned the battle system above
date: but I think it's worth going into more detail because I thought it was one of the best things about the game.  It's definitely an interesting change from the standard JRPG format.  The biggest difference is that you don't give orders to your party members directly.  You group them into squads
hoursPlayed: and you give general orders to each squad
voteText: like "Attack with mystic arts" or "Keep your HP up"
helpfulPercent: and the squad members take whatever actions they can that fit in with your orders.  It adds an interesting bit of tactics and unpredictability to the fights
votesHelpful: especially toward the end when each party member has so many different abilities to choose from.  Except for the main character
votesTotal: the party members also manage their own equipment
votesFunny: so there's not a lot of time spent optimizing each and every one like in some other games.\n\nFinal verdict: if you like JRPGs but you're looking for something a little different from the usual formula
commentsCount: you'll definitely want to check this one out."

reviewText:
Three points to sell this game:

1) The cost is pretty decent, and there's a lot to do in this game (by my definition anyway), so if you can get into it you probably won't be disappointed.

2) It has a neat battle system that isn't the most accommadating, but despite that it feels....I can't quite explain, just fulfilling, plus it has an option to turn on/off these reaction comand type things in battle (I've kept them on just because), so hey, the option is nice. And being a Square game there'll be some moments where you might want to grind, but with the rare monsters you can find here and there it isn't too time consuming.

3) To me, the story feels kind of campy. No real explanation why, but I like it regardless. I love the character design of the races, enemies in this game are intimidating as frick, and the main Bosses get freaking awesome and stupid. It's a round package of everything you love and hate about Square games, so odds are you'll get into a love Triangle with various aspects of the game, if you're a fan of light strategy RPGs and Square bs.

reviewText:
I consider myself to be a big fan of the JRPG genre, having played most of Square / Square Enix’s offerings in the 1990s and 2000s, but The Last Remnant just didn’t do it for me.

The game’s plot is unoriginal and uninspired and the characters are frankly annoying. However, that could be ignored if the gameplay was good. Unfortunately, it isn’t. The Last Remnant’s main problem is that it expects you to make a massive time commitment to it just to do the basics. The combat system is extremely convoluted and the game does a poor job of explaining how everything works. Just walking from one area to another takes forever and feels like a chore.

Unless you’re the world’s biggest JRPG fanboy and/or unemployed give this game a miss.

reviewText:
TL;DR -- Story saves the game from the furnace, but everything else assures it stays in the bargain bin. 4/10

I've tried twice now to like this game. The first was years ago on my Xbox, and now on the PC. The story is appealing and involved, but the main character is a cringeworthy blockhead. I understand at the beginning of the game he's meant to be lovably obtuse; a character meant to have room to grow. But it'll leave you gnashing your teeth at his sheer density more often than not.

Additionally, the game's scaled-down version of Dynasty Warriors it calls a battle system is a hot mess touted as being unique. There are so many things going on at once you're left guessing who's attacking what at any given time. You are encouraged to attack multiple enemies at once due to additional reward drops, but this can be unfair at times. If an NPC-controlled unit contends a player-controlled one, the enemy NPCs usually get a first swing, and rightly so. But I have found, much to my dismay/frustration, that this is STILL the norm even when a player-controlled unit starts a skirmish. Enemies will get to attack you first whether you're on offense/defense, and it has bequeathed me with a Game Over more times than I can count. And if ever you wish to heal your units, you have to break off fighting any enemy units you're currently skirmishing. And you know what that does? You guessed it; it provides the enemy with another chance to attack you.

The game also suffers from an error many of its predecessors have made: level-scaled enemies. No matter how strong your characters get, you're no stronger comparitively to NPCs than you were at level 1. You just dish out bigger numbers against bigger health pools.

Worse still, if you don't have a character in your party, they will not receive XP. Couple this with scaled enemies, and you will have a very, VERY tough time trying to level-up any neglected party members later in the game.

Another minor nit-pick is that the camera controls while using a keyboard do not lock while navigating dialogue or game menus. You will often see the camera pan/jitter while moving up/down/left/right through menu screens, and yes this does happen during battle as well. Again, minor annoyance, but it is pervasive, and for this reason I had to complete the game on my Xbox instead (notice the 1.5 game hours on record).

I feel this game's story was a solid pitch, but then poor dialogue and (english) acting, as well as an experimental battle system gone awry have left it collecting dust. It's unfortunate, considering an epic story is only 1/3 of the formula that makes this genre great--the other 2/3 being story delivery and battle system, where this game falls horribly short.

Can't a guy dream for the return of the original turn-based encounter system? Tried and true, it's what put this genre on its feet. What on earth was so wrong with it? Don't fix something that isn't broken.

11.9GB of squandered potential.

reviewText:
To read other reviews this port is much easier than the original console version. That must have been something because I am still getting my ♥♥♥ kicked just a few hours in at the first serious boss battle. Don't think I'm doing anything obviously wrong either. Given that the game isn't even entirely out of tutorial mode at this point, one might expect a little less of a steep learning curve. As it is, the fun has largely been drained out of it. Some may like it.

That aside, the game is reasonably pretty. The characters display the usual array of JRPG expressions and personae, which can be an acquired taste. But the dialogue, especially in the english dub I suspect, does not flow at all. Long silences between each line, as if the game was loading a new tape each time. That makes it hard to feel engaged in whatever they are saying.

Therefore overall: decent interface, irritating gameplay difficulty, and forgettable / mildly annoying story development: I'll give this game a pass after all.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game i enjoy RPG's and i just finished playing valkyria chronicals and thought this looked like it could be fun. I was mistaken. This game sadly falls into number crunching your party members and hoping for random abilities or battle options to appear before the enemy gets thier opposing random actions or crits. I could be stuck on a battle for an hour and try all kinds of party adjustments, targeting and actions and in the end the battle would only turn out diffrently if i got a critical skill off before the enemy or was lucky enough to press a quick time button in a defense that killed an enemy party instead of just boinking them for 2 damage.

This game acts like theres some strategy but in the end, battles often just fall down to who crits a few times first or randoms some massive skill in their attack action. Whats to bad is the enemy doesn't need these things nearly as much as you do and the resulting difficulty" that is associated with this game is nothing more then redoing a battle enough times until you get the magic combination of chances that result in a win.

Also the main charactor is a 5 year old in a teen body. Brash dumb and whiney dont make for a good main charactor. I can understand if hes supposed to be going through a charactor arc
date: but this kid is an ANNOYING and thoughtless husk. If your going to do childish to start
recommended: give me a Tidus style charactor. Young and naive but with somthing admirable so i dont begin the story by hating him.\n\nDo yourself a favor and avoid this game unless you enjoy rolling dice once every 5 minutes and hoping for double 6's."

reviewText:
Not recommended.  Why?

1. If you don't have an x-box controller you have to interpret and memorize all the keyboard buttons to even play it, because the in-game menus only show the x-box controller icons.

2. The maps are barren and boring.  There is a serious lack of decoration, props, etc.  Almost as bad as Chantelise.

3. You have little control over what the units actually do in combat, and can NOT control individual units.  You get to pick an attack type and go!  The attack is executed by the entire group,  through simulated combat, and it's more CHANCE than tactics.  I played the same battle twice, doing the same thing, and lost once and won once.

reviewText:
As much love as I have for this game, I can clearly say this is one of the games that I will pull up when a friend asks me why I never tell them about obscure games made by high end companies. You should experience it. But if it's your last couple of bucks or you do not want to be cruelly punished for trying to defeat rare game as much as this. Stay away. This seems to be targeted to people who liked everything about final fantasy 12 but the gambit system and having full control over everyone. You have almost no control here, You're pretty much trusting the ai to use from a skillset you create for them to use, though those skills you can turn off, probably need to be on to grow. Go figure. Happy sails to figuring it out, or go find a guide that works, play the game in a linear fashion, or get trolled by the levelling system wondering why enemies aren't dying when they were when you left it. Let me give you a glimpse of what to expect.... Ever played dissidia? got to a high level and turned down your level and watched as everything became easier to do? That's how this gets, But you can't go back, and trading for a weaker party may not help.

I say this, because it is comparable to copying answers on the wrong test. Everything that square excels at is pure gold here. And what they do not do well gets caught through the filter and is easy to spot. Most strategy games will have you building perfect moves and ideas to make the best attacks possible and use them in battle to your own benefit. This does exist, but there is no explanation whatsoever to how this works, and looking it up online takes away from the flavor of playing the game on your own, and it seems very futile without it.

Strategy... Is and isn't here. Obvious options like strike from afar and stay back is normal for most strategy games, but they do not last here. You will end up putting them in the fray or getting them ambushed by using waiting as a strategy. This game is sheer punishment and one wrong turn or missed action could doom you, Autosave exists. Thank the PC gods.

As far as strategy games go, this is comparable to why most games force you to select a loadout before you do anything, you can do this here, but since there is no clear sign to if your unselected skills will grow or not, I leave them on in sheer faith that they will do what is needed, and that leads you to counting mp and tracking commands to predict what moves will show, which works. Another thing that delves from strategy is how often certain individuals reassess the situation and with who and under what limits, Certain groups with high holds of hp will not see danger in not maxing out health and will get you killed. While others who may be useless in battle or offensively grief your unit, will always know when to reassess and who to heal to keep things fresh and alive. Furthermore, the system shines at learning as you go at times, as when you're on the ropes healing just over what you're getting damaged, you'll learn a new skill, and you'll get better at it or beat the opposition afterward.

But the problem is that the game knows what it has to offer, and it does anything it can to ruin it for you. On overpowered bosses? part of the strategy is to die to preserve your unit hp without having enough available units to be overwhelmed by a per unit attack. That is beyond realistic, and is almost impossible to do if you have or learn a revive skill. So you turn it off. Hope the curse kills off one or more of your units, it'll kill the leader and everyone on the team will turn vegetable no matter their own individual rank or standing. So the Marquis will literally just sit there and die, not join a unit or anything, ironically they will last the longest because they retain the group's health pool. Keep all party members and take a critical group attack? Game Over. Take small groups into battle? A direct attack will kill you. Normally you would think, hey, I probably need to gain a few levels and learn some attacks. No, the game has a tiered level system less brutal than xbox, but is more rampant on you developing a strategy closely to luck and hopeful reassessment. You will not notice this until much later, or instantly if you are the thickheaded type to never put down a challenge, which is wholly enabled by a perfect auto save system.

In its entirety, I can compare it to a fighting game, People watching you play will clearly see the holes and imbalances in the strategy and delivery in the game, and call how cheap it is at a constant beat, but when they ask why you still play it... my answer is more of wanting to see how much more obscene the curve balls are going to be, and when they're going to stop tearing holes through groups without fair reason. I'm sure anyone else looking for balance in the game will quickly pick up a guide and follow their lead to a balanced game and read through everything, spoilers included, to see when and where are the best times to defeat and complete enemies and quests. And I can safely say what a shame it is they weren't more introductive to newcomers to the genre as final fantasy is the normal mainstay of square, and even they made gambits a fair and eventually obvious system of priority and functionality.

It'll take time to understand this game, and instead of the normal idea of overpowering enemies that wont take to strategy, You'll have to hoard equipment and hope that your allies take to it, and stop them from trying to snatch orange and yellow rare accessories just because. Which is a complete nuisance. When you get how this game works or when luck favors you, you will save over your game and have a breath of relief, because it's finally over and You won't have to sit curiously staring at the majestic enemy that can and did raze your team at every moment for no favorable reason at all.

I love this game because I can see past this and ignore the fact that I can one shot bosses because a boss I almost defeated at rank 13 is practically impossible at rank 36. It sort of says, hey, the story is free, But the challenge is going to cost you. So when the game has given you a sound beating, you can go back to reading until you're annoyed, and return to try to grab the belt midswing, only finding out that this belt is now a sword and they hope you can figure out how to fight with one hand before... Too late, You died again.

reviewText: The Last Remnant is a game that, at times, will be unforgiving. The very beginning of the game, RNG can take you for a ride, and before you know it you have game over'd on the first fight. The combat system is unique, leaving unions to choose their specific attacks. This allows the fight to feel more real than having units spam the same move multiple times. The story isn't as expected, as the story seems to make one think how did it all happen the way it did. Overall, I would recommend this game not on the premise for the story, but for the unique combat system.

reviewText:
As much love as I have for this game, I can clearly say this is one of the games that I will pull up when a friend asks me why I never tell them about obscure games made by high end companies. You should experience it. But if it's your last couple of bucks or you do not want to be cruelly punished for trying to defeat rare game as much as this. Stay away. This seems to be targeted to people who liked everything about final fantasy 12 but the gambit system and having full control over everyone. You have almost no control here, You're pretty much trusting the ai to use from a skillset you create for them to use, though those skills you can turn off, probably need to be on to grow. Go figure. Happy sails to figuring it out, or go find a guide that works, play the game in a linear fashion, or get trolled by the levelling system wondering why enemies aren't dying when they were when you left it. Let me give you a glimpse of what to expect.... Ever played dissidia? got to a high level and turned down your level and watched as everything became easier to do? That's how this gets, But you can't go back, and trading for a weaker party may not help.

I say this, because it is comparable to copying answers on the wrong test. Everything that square excels at is pure gold here. And what they do not do well gets caught through the filter and is easy to spot. Most strategy games will have you building perfect moves and ideas to make the best attacks possible and use them in battle to your own benefit. This does exist, but there is no explanation whatsoever to how this works, and looking it up online takes away from the flavor of playing the game on your own, and it seems very futile without it.

Strategy... Is and isn't here. Obvious options like strike from afar and stay back is normal for most strategy games, but they do not last here. You will end up putting them in the fray or getting them ambushed by using waiting as a strategy. This game is sheer punishment and one wrong turn or missed action could doom you, Autosave exists. Thank the PC gods.

As far as strategy games go, this is comparable to why most games force you to select a loadout before you do anything, you can do this here, but since there is no clear sign to if your unselected skills will grow or not, I leave them on in sheer faith that they will do what is needed, and that leads you to counting mp and tracking commands to predict what moves will show, which works. Another thing that delves from strategy is how often certain individuals reassess the situation and with who and under what limits, Certain groups with high holds of hp will not see danger in not maxing out health and will get you killed. While others who may be useless in battle or offensively grief your unit, will always know when to reassess and who to heal to keep things fresh and alive. Furthermore, the system shines at learning as you go at times, as when you're on the ropes healing just over what you're getting damaged, you'll learn a new skill, and you'll get better at it or beat the opposition afterward.

But the problem is that the game knows what it has to offer, and it does anything it can to ruin it for you. On overpowered bosses? part of the strategy is to die to preserve your unit hp without having enough available units to be overwhelmed by a per unit attack. That is beyond realistic, and is almost impossible to do if you have or learn a revive skill. So you turn it off. Hope the curse kills off one or more of your units, it'll kill the leader and everyone on the team will turn vegetable no matter their own individual rank or standing. So the Marquis will literally just sit there and die, not join a unit or anything, ironically they will last the longest because they retain the group's health pool. Keep all party members and take a critical group attack? Game Over. Take small groups into battle? A direct attack will kill you. Normally you would think, hey, I probably need to gain a few levels and learn some attacks. No, the game has a tiered level system less brutal than xbox, but is more rampant on you developing a strategy closely to luck and hopeful reassessment. You will not notice this until much later, or instantly if you are the thickheaded type to never put down a challenge, which is wholly enabled by a perfect auto save system.

In its entirety, I can compare it to a fighting game, People watching you play will clearly see the holes and imbalances in the strategy and delivery in the game, and call how cheap it is at a constant beat, but when they ask why you still play it... my answer is more of wanting to see how much more obscene the curve balls are going to be, and when they're going to stop tearing holes through groups without fair reason. I'm sure anyone else looking for balance in the game will quickly pick up a guide and follow their lead to a balanced game and read through everything, spoilers included, to see when and where are the best times to defeat and complete enemies and quests. And I can safely say what a shame it is they weren't more introductive to newcomers to the genre as final fantasy is the normal mainstay of square, and even they made gambits a fair and eventually obvious system of priority and functionality.

It'll take time to understand this game, and instead of the normal idea of overpowering enemies that wont take to strategy, You'll have to hoard equipment and hope that your allies take to it, and stop them from trying to snatch orange and yellow rare accessories just because. Which is a complete nuisance. When you get how this game works or when luck favors you, you will save over your game and have a breath of relief, because it's finally over and You won't have to sit curiously staring at the majestic enemy that can and did raze your team at every moment for no favorable reason at all.

I love this game because I can see past this and ignore the fact that I can one shot bosses because a boss I almost defeated at rank 13 is practically impossible at rank 36. It sort of says, hey, the story is free, But the challenge is going to cost you. So when the game has given you a sound beating, you can go back to reading until you're annoyed, and return to try to grab the belt midswing, only finding out that this belt is now a sword and they hope you can figure out how to fight with one hand before... Too late, You died again.

reviewText: KUPO!\nWhen it first released for the Xbox 360, I was excited. Though it's price was steep and I decided to wait for it to drop. I waited MANY years for it to happen. I started to worry if I should regret the wait, but I bought it recently (Aug. 2014) and I KNOW it was a good choice to wait. It says that it's not compatible with Laptop systems, but I'm using an old Asus (mid year) 2012 laptop and it runs well enough for me to enjoy it. Al I had to do was sacrifice the graphics, which is fine for me. I have them set to the most minimal setting available. I am REALLY enjoying this title. If you like any of the Final Fantasy titles that have been released by Equare Enix (aka Squaresoft and Enix after they merged), I believe you will enjoy this tale. It's unique turn-based fighting system and it's progressive story make up for all the loss I had to give up to play (i.e. the graphics). I especially appreciate Sqare Enix's new system settings for this title. They allow you to adjust the game from the language text, language spoken, all the way through bindings of the controller, keyboard and mouse, and even allow you to adfjust the graphics and hardware settings. As a veteran player of over 20 Squaresoft/Square Enix titles, I give this one a 9/10 score :3\nKupo!

reviewText:
basically only buy this if you're an experienced jrpg fan

the battle system is the strongest point of the game for me as its a really interesting mix of JRPG turn based combat with elements from strategy games. but i've also heard the exact opposite opinion from people who liked everything else in the game so much that they put up with the combat. so idk, maybe there's a little something in this game for everyone?

the battle system is really fun and is full of a lot of interesting mechanics, but the game isn't exactly top notch at explaining it all. it took me 3/4ths of the game to feel like i completely understood the battle mechanics, and even then i found myself a little confused or frustrated at times. the battles sometimes feel very random but often times the only thing that decides the winner is your own strategy

personally i found the story to be really boring and unengaging, but not enough that it made me stop caring. there was interest in seeing where the story went, but i didn't feel like i really cared what happened. i just wanted to know

the difficulty of the game is also skewed as ♥♥♥♥, there were boss battles that i had to retry over and over that were side by side with boss battles i felt were extremely underwhelming. maybe i was doing something very wrong

also 75% of the content of this game is sidequests. if that's your thing then cool but i found it very weird that there were entire cities and full dungeons that i wouldn't have known about if i hadn't stopped in at a town's pub. also a lot of the sidequests don't feel that special, it's often just going to a dungeon and getting to the end" of it.

i've said a lot of bad things about the game but it honestly is worth playing
date: especially at its price. i got a good 60 hours out of it and that's only with half the sidequests done. i really enjoyed creating parties and seeing what worked in battles and i really enjoyed the larger scale wars
recommended: even though there weren't too many. the story isn't that bad but i couldn't care less about the characters. idk. if you're big on rpgs with interesting battle systems i absolutely recommend this"

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a game I'd recommend, however, only to a certain type of player. In this review I'll try to go over what I liked and what frustrated me, to try and give a clearer picture for those looking to buy.

I should note, I finished with 95 hours played at BR45. This was also completing most of the side quests as well as recruiting all major leaders, I also did a small amount of rare monster hunting.
I also edited files to give the game a larger FOV and reduced texture pop in, I high recommend doing the same before playing, you can find a guide detailing how here on Steam.

Here's what I liked:

The graphics, this game looks fantastic. The remnants are wonderful to view and the small areas of the citys you can visit are well detailed (this does not include the bland dungeons).

The large amount of items, drops and weapons. If resource gathering, crafting and mining is your thing, TLR's got you covered. The game contains tons of different items and components. You can go down many different weapon tree's, crafting better version of each weapons, turning them into more deadly looking tools. There's a fair amount of rare and boss weapon drops in the game too.

The variation of combat arts and mystic arts. These's are the ability's your characters will learn and perform. There's a huge amount, most look fairly wonderful to watch. It's also nice to assign certain Leader's to specialize in these area's.

The music. This game has some fantastic music, tracks like Swirling Sands from the Great Sand Sea are a favourite.

The menu's and IU. It's a fairly important part of an RPG, this game nails it. It's clean, slick and easy to use.

Here's some things I didn't like:

You can't manually select what a character cast during battle. I see what Square Enix was trying to do here, but it simply ended up with you turn different move's on and off before battle, just so your desired move was forced to come up during battle. It ended up becoming annoying more than anythign else.

When you most need a certain command during battle, it won't show. Let's say I only have one Union left, I want to revive my other downed Unions, the game will at times, only give me attack commands rather than showing me something I really need.

Poor character development. Firstly, Rush is out right annoying and the few characters who have likable personalities aren't explored, they're left to occational one liners.

Battle's a boring at first. TLR is a hard game. Until you open up the better moves and are able to create more interesting Unions the battles feel alot like pressing the same button and watching a short cutscene until it's over. Now this changes somewhat later on. Anyone who's played Final Fantasy 13 will understand this very problem.

I would say The Last Remnant is an aquired taste. The more I played it, the better and more interesting it's mechanic's and features got. Anyone who's interested in a challenging JRPG will want to give this a go. If you're looking for something more traditional, this may not be for you.

If you're unsure my advise would be to YouTube some gameplay videos, flick over the different mechanic's on this game wonderful Wiki.

reviewText:
Do you like RPGs? If yes proceed to the next question.
Do you like grinding? If no you can stop here, you might need some patience and time to play this game.

If you are expecting a A-RPG, do not be fooled this game is not that.

Last remnant is a fantastic JRPG with a novel combat system that feels like a breeze of fresh air in this game industry where every game last 5 hours and is full of cinematics (there are plenty of cinematics in TLR do not fear). The combat system feels random at times until you learn how the system works, problem is this is going to take at least 50h and you are not going to have a grasp of all the things you can actually do. The story is alright, considering the main character is less charismatic than a potato and he is annoying as hell, but a mysterious and charismatic antagonist pays off.

Pros:

- Cheap.
- Loads of content and beautiful areas.
- Really nice visuals.
- AoE synergies and group building.
- Difficulty through the roof, that makes you build up some self confidence when you get to kill THAT ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ MONS-- er.
- ♥♥♥♥ loads of upgrades to weapons and skills.
- Customization of your units and characters make the game an experience every time you play it.

Cons:
- Main character annoying as hell.
- Side quests blocking the full content of the game, especially in some cases when you needed to do a quest from Disc 1 in order to go into a new zone (e.g. The ancient runes.)
- Guild rewards need you to kill some random monster that has a 0.01% spawn ratio.
- Almost mandatory to follow a guide during your first playthrough.

Veredict: 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
got this game on a friend's recomendation. Not sure if It was a mistake or not..

I'm going to break down the pros/cons here:

Pro: Combat is fun
Pro: resource collecting/customizing is fun

Con: voice acting is super dull
Con: generic story that wasn't keeping my interest
Con: in the first 50 minutes every single character has annoyed me for 100% of every cutscene (bad writing)
Con: unnatural dialouge
Con: the animations are very stiff

bought it thinking I'd be able to sink hours into it, unfortunately I need an enticing story or likable characters, otherwise the fun combat goes to waste

reviewText: Being a fan of a lot of square enix games i REALLY REALLY wanted to like this game... But it suffers from one major flaw, you don't really play the game. I understand a difficult game I do enjoy a challenge but lets be fair here, challengeing because you had to plan ahead, and challengeing because your luck was bad are two completely different things. One example is an easy first boss fight, that i had to do twelve different times and still could not beat. First of all you may die before you EVEN ENGAGE in the battle because of dumb luck. Second you engage in the battle and whatever order you give may just not play out right for some reason, and you never really know the reason why its just ends up feeling like somebody flipped a coin somewhere and said ♥♥♥♥ it. Then you get lucky and can issue an actual battle order but only for yourself hoping that whatever ally you don't control does what you want it to... Did I mention the fact that you can't really control all your party members, you just issue orders and hope they do what you want. I know this is the way the gameplay was designed but it was a poor design choice because I don't really feel like I am controlling anything. Also I might add that as you level up the enemies get harder, while this seems like a good thing at first, its not... You have a difficult boss fight and want to do some griding to come back later to try to beat him... too bad he is just as hard because he leveled up. Want to do some side quests  just to get away from the main story? well damnit now all the bosses and enemies are harder. This game literally punishes you for doing side quests, yea its that annoying. If you enjoy this game thats fine, more power to you and I am glad you did, but for any newcomers please be wary that this game is extremely convoluted and frustrating.

reviewText: Experimental battle system you don't have a lot of control over : as in FFXIII, you give general commands only (at least, FFXIII gave you the opportunity to select the skills you want to use, even if it's useless). This game was an obvious design blueprint for the awful FFXIII battle system. You are supposed to leads groups of warrior, positionning is sometimes key to victory or defeat and, guess what ? You have absolutely no control over it. NONE. So much for strategy. Battle QTEs are anecdotic (for crits), chara design is... meh, and the characters themselves BEG FOR YOU TO B****SLAP THEIR STUPID FACES. This game signs the demise of Square as a JRPG monument on the third generation of consoles. The story is... well, the standard jrpg story : symbolic princess is kidnapped, go for her, make friends, be betrayed from time to time, the ennemies are controled by something bigger than you are supposed to expect, then save the world from apocalypse. Yaaaaay....\nDon't buy this game. Don't enable SE for more mediocrity.

While people with a taste for story-driven JRPGs may have more endurance than I, I only made it 8 hours into the game before I gave up hope for its salvation. reviewText:
I bought this a long time and put it down cause I could get a handle on the control.  I decide to give it second chance and try to work though it by playing the first couple battles and rebinding my key but this port is hopeless.

Its bad enough that the default controls are complete worthless to anyone with less than 4 arms, (requires hand on wsda, and arrow keys to move and if you want toggle targets proper hand on mouse as well, as well key bound to everywhere else on your keyboard from esc to home.  Then you have to deal with the fact that all the on screen indicators are using X-box button Icons.  Once you get all that sorted I guess you go to the menu and do your own custom bindings.  Well that would be great but every time I bind one key another one unbinds for no apparent reason, I guess on an X-box controller you have the same key in multiple function in different menus/cases and the game cant seem to handle that properly or cant tell the difference between arrows, num keys and arrow keys unless you bind them in specific order, Im honestly not sure whats going.

Also continous screen tearing, no matter how I set frame settings.

Game might be buried in history but anyone who comes across beware, X-box control is a must if you want to avoid a huge headache.

reviewText:
Not my cup of tea this one.

Like most of Square Enix's games, The Last Remnant features a standard spiky hair teenager you'd see in a subpar anime or JRPG.

STORY- Something about demons and his sister? These stories are all the same.
GRAPHICS- Simulating big battles in the background is one thing The Last Remnant does very well.
SOUNDTRACK- meh
GAMEPLAY- I'm not even sure you can call it gameplay.
Pros-
The battles look huge and awesome later on
Multiple ways to set up squad composition
JRPG that discourages level grinding?
Complex combat system

Cons-
Complex combat system (Like myself, most players who start the game will have no idea how everything comes together in combat and leveling. I didn't realize grinding early was bad, considering all the people I tried to recruit afterwards sucked. High BR = Bad)
Yet you still need to do all the side quests just to prevent a wipe from a boss?
Whether you grind or not, it's still difficult
Takes a little bit to get multiple squads (So you can enjoy those big battles)
Individual actions for squad members cannot be selected. (Game revolves around tactical choices for each squad that determine what actions they will likely take. But, it's better than selecting 18 individual unit actions separately)

CONCLUSION-
This game is not for those looking for a traditional JRPG. Similar to the SaGa series, The Last Remnant has no character development or decent plot, and has a different combat and leveling system compared to oldies like Final Fantasy or Breath of Fire. If you've been fishing out SaGa games out of the trash like I have, you may enjoy this game. I however, enjoyed Unlimited SaGa more than this weird game.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
By all counts, I should hate The Last Remnant.

The battles are long, control over characters seems to be random, there are an endless amount of missables, you need to grind for items to upgrade character weapons...

And yet despite it all, I'm finding myself really, really invested in this game. The story is convoluted and I'm not sure I'm completely following the lore, but I'm enjoying the characters a lot. Even the side characters who don't show up in any major cut scenes, whose characterization can be condensed to five lines of backstory... even those, I find them to be rich and strangely well crafted.

I could, theoretically, just plow ahead, and play simply the story. But I am actually enjoying doing the many many many many sidequests, and I've been keeping track with an FAQ to make sure I don't miss any. And you will miss some, if you aren't paying a lot of attention to what you're doing.

If you have the patience for the game, if you are willing to accept that you will never understand all the systems, if you can handle the somewhat random nature of the battles -- then, yes, I absolutely recommend it.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a unique title. It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing. The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right? Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.

What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay. When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before. What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES. Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads. This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not. This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.

This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while. The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch. If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Had potential to be a great game, yet seems unpolished.

Story is fine. Enough to keep you hooked.

Gameplaywise  it's fairly good.
Big fights with decent strategic freedom, although way too many formations to choose from.

Not to mention that the tooltips are pretty vague and sometimes even mistranslated.
Certain items effects don't do what they're saying in the tooltip, and others are plain cryptic
to you unless you go through the trouble of wiki-researching it.

Another mystery is the leveling system, which isn't anywhere near adequately explained in
the game. This can cause frustrations, since you don't really have a good idea of how strong
you are, until you get your head kicked in by a boss. Most of which are pretty tough.

It's a risky buy.
I can see how a lot of people would quit the game halfway through, given the negatives I mentioned.
But if it's 70% off, as it was for me, I'd take it.

reviewText: The Last Remnant got an awfully bad rap from the critics, but that's only because most critics never played the updated, polished PC version which removes much of the Xbox version's annoyances (and because most critics are pompous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who evaluate a game based on all criteria except 'is it fun to play').\n\nThe Last Remnant is a jRPG which deviates from the traditional Square Enix style, in that your characters are grouped into unions, who basically do what they want and only obey general guidelines you, as the player, give them. The Xbox version suffered from several flaws, (choppy graphics, inability to recruit more than a handful of Leaders, and inbalanced level scaling), but the PC version fixes all that. In jRPG tradition, there's some annoying voices and narrative head-scratchers, but it is a game well-worth picking up!
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Sick of hack n' slash action games posing as the real deal? This is a great way for PC gamers to play a turn-based, strategic RPG, which unfortunately, has been a dying genre for the platform since the 90s. I don't like that it eschews a world map (a terrible trend in Japanese RPGs). However, some of the areas are vast enough to give the feel of a world map, even if you are just picking names of places to go. This isn't as good as Final Fantasy XII, the only FF that wasn't garbage after IX, but it gets the job done. The battle system could have offered more control, but it adds a different kind of strategy with who to target, and when to use what commands you are given the option to use. The texture pop-in of the UT3 engine is bad, and the cutscenes look like crap even after forcing v sync with a third-party app, but the towns and the remnants look cool. There are also many sidequests, and you'll probably need to do a lot of them because the boss battles can be rough.

reviewText:
Certainly is underrated. Story is alright for a JRPG. Its full of traditional JRPG tropes so not too much new there. The protagonist is a sis-con/etc. However, where it becomes more unique is in party formations. This is like an RPG game with a heavier emphasis on setting up your parties to handle all threats. It is a different and welcome approach. Because of this, some fights can be much harder than they need be.

You'll likely find lots of people complaining about the difficulty. But here is probably the greatest tip of all and it didn't take much to figure out. Yes some are hard, but they all have optimal strategies to make them work. It isn't luck of the draw. Luck only comes in when it comes to damage/resist totals. Overall instead of simple luck, it usually involves who you target first. If you are having trouble, try other combinations. I've had some tough ones become insanely easy because instead of focusing down one enemy, I focused another. Or instead of splitting up, I focused.

The other big factor for this game is do a search on it for how to manually set the graphics/etc. Square - Enix did a pretty poor job. But there are wikis out there which will quickly tell you how to set the game up to look much better. It literally is a must do for anyone who buys this game. Read the sites, hack the ini, enjoy the game.

It is a shame this title didn't get more refinement or better support from Square. Certainly is one of the more unique JRPGs out there. Play it in the Japanese dub if possible. The mannerisms and voices match much better. However, the English subs are sometimes grossly off the mark. If you know any Japanese, you'll notice right away when you come to a scene and wonder who translated it because what they are saying and what the text reads is not close.

reviewText:
This game repeadily screws with you until you no longer want to play it. Doing side quests and grinding makes the game harder due to level scailing to the point where I can no longer progress because I never bother learning all the little intricacies of gearing every character in your party and leading the party members into the right skills. Since you can't manually do any of it, you'd never know what you were doing if you don't use a wiki, which I didn't which is why I got screwed. Why you can'd just equipe your party normally is beyond me. Pretty much everything is a chore to do since you can only tell a party member to focus on something and then they need to take gear from your inventory when they want it, at random. This wouldn't be so bad if the game wasn't so difficult because of the combat system.

The combat system is terrible. You can't tell your party to do anything you want, It's all decided by RNG. Every turn it's 3 options of attack the enemy, which all do pretty much the same thing unless you have the wiki open and know exactly what is useful against what enemies. Then you do the QTEs to win which if you miss you you lose most of your damage. Some times randomly maybe you get an option to heal which is always nice to have but they don't always give it to you when you need it. It's infuriating to be fiting a hard enemy for 20 minutes of attrition and then they just don't let you heal for a turn and you lose. WTF GAME?  You can't even defend and stand still because standing still means you lose all your morale if you get attacked, they punish you for not attacking. Positioning is next to impossible since you can't choose to move, only to attack someone and choosing to stand still is asking to lose if there is any enemies that aren't locked in combat. Attacking with multiple unions on a boss is also terrible a lot of the time since bosses get to attack every union that attack them. Which means they can hit you with AOEs more option.

The bosses will repeatedly do AOEs which can wipe a union in 1 hit and they can hit all unions in range. So since you can't move, you are at the mercy of the boss RNG of chosing to do the AOEs and how many of your units are in range because that is all controlled by RNG. I can't imagine how they expect people to approach the battle strategically when they give you no options in the battle. Every boss battle feels like flipping a coin because you need to dodge some AOEs or you'd lose. There is no other way arround it. The AOEs will 1 hit KO a full union if they hit.

Overall, the game just isn't for me and it pisses me off so much that it made my write this review. Mainly because I played more than 40 hours of it and I can't even progress any more. I am now stuck unless I want to cheat or something. I saved accidentally at a part I can't progress pass because the boss is too hard and I can't even leave because the game locks me from leaving the area until I beat said boss.

I actually enjoyed the idea of controlling a large group of units in an army like this but this game feels like it just want to screw with me every chance it gets. There is no logic to the combat system at times and it is all a long gind. Even with all that I would have been happy if I just got to the of the game but the game won't even give me that.

reviewText:
The Last Remnant's progression makes almost no sense without reading guides making it stupidly difficult to enjoy unless you like alt+tabbing out constantly to look where you can get items and/or strategies.

I like doing side content in most games, but not in this game. You'll get a quest, cheese through the trash creatures and then be faced with an impossible boss that forces you to ditch the quest. Though the 'rare' creatures are optional I like to take them on at the time of encountering them, and there in lies the issue. You encounter ridiculously strong random rare creatures in dungeons which can obliterate a union (a group unit) in 1 attack round. And in many cases that attack is also AoE and takes the majority HP of another union nearby.

Theres a 'flanking' system in the game where if more than one of your 'unions' attacks the same creature you get a damage bonus. Great right? However, every boss and rare can take on multiple of your unions without ever getting flanked because they can do something called 'multi deadlock' which then also allows them to attack multiple times in a single round. And if that creature decides to do it's big attack twice in the same turn kiss your a** goodbye.

Your party members get new abilities along the way, which is nice. But the game picks 4-6 cookie cutter attack patterns based on health, AP, etc. I ended up grouping Rush with Torgal, but because Torgal's combat arts were so strong the game never gave me an option to ever use Rush's combat abilities unless I had built up a ridiculous amount of AP.

There's a morale indicator in each battle. Who knows why. You either handlily destroy your enemies and it's all the way to one side, or you take a bad hit and watch it go completely in the enemies favor at which point it ain't never coming back.

Speaking of useless things there's also a minimap in each battle that shows you the location of every union. But even if you set your unions to attack the closest enemy unions somehow there are still interferences and interceptions. Which makes absolutely no sense how the game judges distances and deadlocks. This part is particularrly annoying because you can send your best union against a larger enemy union, but then the game randomly decides that another enemy union of 1 NPC interceps that union, and then you basically lose 3 of your most powerful attacks for the round.

Overall, if the fights weren't completely one-sided 99% of the time it might be worth continuing. But as is I either destroy the trash NPCs, or get completely blown out by a boss/rare. So overall it's just not a fun game.

reviewText:
Square Enix qualtity graphics, unfortunatelly there is where pros ends.

Gameplay depends too much on luck and is FULL of bad implemented mechanics that RUINS your experience.I dont bother any longer with this game cause my time is just more precious and it is typical to find a battle way too difficult for the moment you decide to fight ( veteran player here, not kidding ). No much sense on coming back later, or grinding your level cause mobs escale with you and trying a typical sidequest to improve gear can get you to 30 min battle for reach a boss, just to have your whole party one-hit killed... no way to know the difficult an encounter can be until your teams are wiped on the 27 turn by one attack... you can get random monsters, random spawns, enemy reinforcements that appears and lay waste to your troops without you even having the chance to choice your next turn random comands... yup, there are long ( long ) battles , and for a development reason i cant fathom to understand, the choice of orders is random... so you can find yourself with no heal orders at all... and your party will be wiped on any turn.

I dont use to give up with games but this one just dont deserve my time.

reviewText:
Well, this is a Square Enix game, turn based basic combat.

I thought that the squad-based thing might remove some of the parts I find boring in the normal turn based systems, but overall, it makes for a fairly dull system.

I only had the patience to go through the first two areas, so it might get a bit better later on, but so far, here is what I found wrong with it:

- The movements on the map scenes are slow.
- The environments are empty, adding to the slow movements.
- Everything dies in a few hits, both you and the enemies (even in the first area), but the HP is restored to full after each fight.

reviewText: From Squeenix comes a fairly fun, non-traditional JRPG. The graphics, IMHO, are stunning, and the gameplay is simple enough to gain good control over if you simply pay attention to the tutorials that pop up when they are needed. One word of advice: in battling multiple foes, take out the ones that would flank you first. Honestly a very nice game, pretty decent story and full of painfully funny dialogue. I don't know if it's for everyone, but if you enjoyed Final Fantasy in its day and want a fantastic graphical update with a lot of fun mixed in, it's one to consider

reviewText:
Last Remnant is a reminder to any Square fan, of how far they have fallen from the RPG tree. What could've been a solid RPG, looks like it was never play tested and still is treated like that to this day. Square treats the consumer as if they are mentally challenged, and it's clear with this game.

Why is the player unable to equip other party members? Why are they forced into classes that don't even sound neat or interesting? Why were so many monster sprites reused so much? Why are rare monsters so freaking hard? Why is the player formations limited to 18 characters when you have 4 unions that can hold up to 20 characters? It makes no sense.

This is the ball, and this is Square continuing to drop it

reviewText:
This game is falsely categorized, it lets you role play as one character with linear plot.... that’s an adventure not an RPG. Combat itself in the game is terrible, you choose from a set of skills that you know almost nothing about. As for the game explaining things, it will have tutorial pop-ups every time it invents a new phrase for the game to let you know how the battle is going, it doesn’t however explain how chests work and whether you can receive all the loot or only one. It doesn’t let you know how strong an enemy is till you fight it. There are uncommon monsters that if you fight them and die that monster then you can never encounter that monster again. (that specific monster, not that type of monster) There are lots of items that you can find in monsters corpses but the game makes it very difficult to know what any of the items do other than be sold to merchants for coins. The game controls are terrible, it looks like it was made for xbox but then was never finished being integrated into PC controls. The game has the 3rd person viewpoint camera barely move around on its own, and the only other way to control the camera is with arrow-keys. The game didn’t take the time to configure the mouse to be bound to anything, which is a waste of potential camera control. When you want to engage an enemy while getting initiative (slight damage bonus) you have to press 3 different keys! you have to press F or G to get your character to look at them, V to be ready for battle, then SPACEBAR to start the battle. The English and the Japanese dialog was poorly written; the English has the character constantly speak is phrases that seem irrelevant. The plot and character development was poor; the main characters see a winged beast at the beginning and the sister is kidnapped, but when they saw the enemy in that scene they realized it was hostile, then proceeded to calmly wait for the enemy to fly over and attack. After this you end up on a plain with 2 armys charging each other for no reason... then you meet a prince who agrees to help you recover your sister, but then just sits on the throne and provides info. There was also technical incongruities, such as the necklace that the main character wears around his neck disappears randomly from time to time. (this isn’t a glitch, its also not in cut scenes)

Positives:
-has Japanese as a dialog option
-has relatively original plot (for better or for worse)
-has appropriate background music...
-has Kingdom Hearts quality of graphics

reviewText:
Interesting game, with beautiful graphics and battle mecanics. However, i can't recomend this game since i'm using a PC and this game was made for consoles. All the information, hints, pop-up messages and etc, only indicates buttons for a console controller and i'm playing on the PC, so you can imagine the mess it is.
You need to memorize the entire keyboard layout used by the game, and there's 3 different keyboard layouts, each one used for a specific event (one for battle, one for navigation, one for menus in general).
Anyway, the game appears do be very nice, but the lack of customization for PCs makes the experience more frustrating than enjoyable. I'm already expect this kind of issue in japanese games (Valkyria Chronicles, and some others that i already played), but The Last Remnant really pushes this way beyond.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, but it's too obtuse to play and have fun with respect to the combat system.  You need a spreadsheet to do the combat correctly, and simply grinding to attempt to become powerful will backfire and you'll be unable to effectivley fight, because you'll have made the monsters too powerful.

Unlike every other JRPG in existance, grinding normally will cause you to have a failed-beyond-repair playthrough, rather than an easier time.

The formation and union system is difficult to understand, and it's not the good kind of difficult, it's just aggrivating.  The game punishes you just for trying to play it and not sweat all the details it doesn't explain, but offers no remedy for this other than starting a new game.

If you have a masochistic strain of autism I'm sure you'd love this game, but if you just want to have fun with a modern JRPG, this isn't the game for you.

It's a shame they created a game which requires a walkthrough and multiple guides for the various subsystems it doesn't explain to any useful depth, because this game had a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Not the worst JRPG you've played, but it's the most frustrating and annoying of them...
-Keyboard+mouse controls... looks like people who ported the game saw K+M for the first time in their lives, gamepad is strongly recommended.
-VERY limited control of your units. Every turn you have 5 random options to chose from and thats it. You might have no option to heal when you're desperately in need of it and you might be screwed even if you have it cause you can heal with ITEMS or MAGIC or both and you will get the one which isn't so powerful.
-No matter what, your weakest union WILL be gangraped 99% of the time, every monster on the field wants their blood.
-Monster AOE spells are overpowered beyond belief, even the weakest monster in the area (~same level as you) can onesot your party in 1 turn. Lets say normal monster attack hits for 100, singletarget ability hits for 300, AOE ability hits for 300 every unit in your union, which will result in 1500 damage on 5ppl... Some BIG monsters can AOE multiple unions and erase your party in a single spell... and they will cast it FREQUENTLY.
-You can't surrender, so if you're trying to beat a very strong rare enemy and it destroys half or your units on the first turn... you must watch the other half die, sometimes very slowly.
-You CAN'T skip cutscenes. After some cutscenes you will be immediately thrown into battle, and if you lose it... load your save and watch 5+ min cutscene again.
-You can equip only your main protagonist, others can only request some components and RARELY items from your inventory, so you can sit on a pile of top gear and no ability to use it. It's not a huge minus anyway, cause all you have is main/offhand weapon and 2 accessory slots.
-Though locations are pretty unique and well done you will be forced to visit them over and over again if you want to complete sidequests or hunt for rare monsters for the guild. Every quest teleports you to corresponding location and teleports back to tavern IMMEDIATELY after it's completion.
-The world and lore are really interesting, but the story feels like it's written for the 12 y/o. This flaw" can be seen in almost every Japanese game (atleast in my experience) and can be forgiven.
-Battle system is pretty good for a JRPG
date: but it's very annoying that you can't skip battles with weak monsters when revisiting old locations.\nI'd give it 6/10
recommended: but put a huge red FRUSTRATION WARNING on it."

reviewText: Unfortunately this game is broken.  After 20 hours of play, I reached a point where I could not proceed anymore because of a boss that I was under leveled for.  Yeah yeah yeah, I could have used multiple save files, but the game really shouldn't let you steam roll through a dungeon only to have the boss be insurmountable.  Furthermore, if said boss is impossible, there should be minions to grind on in the vicinity, allowing the player an opportunity to grind and proceed.  This game basically locked me in a room with no way out, and because I didn't save outside of this area, I simply can't proceed.  You can argue it's partially my fault, and that's fair, but it is still very bad game design.  It's really ashamed because the story and graphics are actually quite good, and the battle system has some merits.  That said, I will still not be trekking back through to make up my lost progress.  Unless you are going to play this game using a guide or a wiki, don't bother with it.

reviewText:
Do you like grinding?
Do you like minimal control over your characters?
Do you like almost no customization options for party members?
Do you like a cringe-worthy story with cutscenes playing out like a complete amateur scripted them?
Do you like poorly ported controls and optimization?

Then The Last Remnant is the game for you.

Grinding
Almost every part of the game requires some degree of grinding. Let me elaborate. You are advancing in the story. You just unlocked a new place to visit. But wait! If you do not re-visit the previously visited stories and kill every single enemy 3 times, you are not going to have a chance against the enemies in the new area!
What is that? You just did that and are no longer having problems with fighting enemies in the new area, even if you aggro 5 groups at a time?
I guess that means you can go fight the boss, right? Whoops, he instakilled you because your level is too low. If you exit the area and clear all its enemies 3 more times, the boss will actually only deal about half as much damage! That works every time!
Coincidentally, the only parts that are not grindy or fetch-quests are essentially the tutorials and early side-quests, because they automatically teleport you to the area you are goign to, initiate the thing you are supposed to do, and teleport you back to the quest NPC to give you a reward, all automatically. Which is not really that good at teaching you anything, but at least you do not have to grind.

Control
Every action you have in a fight will have a pre-determined combination of actions, depending on how many action points you have. Half the time, there is no option for ranged attacks, even if you are able to do them. When you are healing yourself with white majykks, all non-healers will stand by. If you use the option that allows you to attack AND heal, your characters will prioritize using items, unless they have no item skills, even if their magic is stronger. If you let them play by ear, which is supposed to let each character in a squad attack the way they want to, they'll just auto-attack without using skills most of the time, even if you have 100+ AP and their skills cost 7.

Management
The only way you can customize any character except the MC (Rush Sykes) is by deciding whether you will let them take your loot to upgrade their weapons or not. Other than that, you can only tug them in the right direction by spamming commands that will increase a certain skill or attribute if used a lot, but that will unbalance your entire party and make them less efficient, since Legions normally have a mix of melee and caster characters.

The rest of my points speak for themselves.

reviewText: Before i start, i almost always finish games i start, even if they are bad. This game however got to a point that it was unwinable. The console version was apparently too easy so they ramped up the difficulty scaling on the pc version, which they overdid. Im still interested in the story, i just got to the point where i couldnt kill anything, and to fix it i would have to scrap my save and start again. Ill elaborate though... there are no levels in this game, your main character just gets ranks which are like level ups where you get random points based on what you killed. HOWEVER the game tricks you into thinking you can just fight large groups of enemies to get a larger reward, what it really means is to ONLY fight the tough enemies, otherwise when you rank up you get points based on the weak enemies, which is to say you barely get stat increases but the enemies get tougher. Rank up enough this way and the game becomes unwinnable. I only found out what i was doing wrong about half way into the game and the only way to correct it is to start from the beginnning again. I couldnt do any of the sidequests to beat elite enemies because they often just one shotted me. That said the correct way of playing this game is to pick up the strongest allies, avoid every enemy you can and only fight bosses or elite enemies as part of sidequests to keep your rank down as low as it can go. This game greatly discourages revisiting areas and grinding (such as farming the parts to craft a good weapon). I may someday return to this game in an attempt to beat it, but having to restart because i farmed too much seems like a bad gameplay design.

reviewText:
It's funny how most negative ones are from noobs who can't use their non-existent brains.
This game is AMAZING. It's beautiful, and it runs perfectly even on my 10 year old PC! The battle system is NOT a mess, if you spend a few minutes thinking about it, it's all quite clear. Also, when your team can heal, you ALWAYS get the option, despite what some noob below wrote. ;)
The story is freaking awesome, the characters are lovely (I mean, come on, a Duke guy who's not a ♥♥♥♥ to you? The main boss guy's voice (original, that is) acting makes you want to join him instead of trying to pöwn his butt, etc. It's fun, it's funny, it's sad, sometimes it's hilarious, and it's pretty easy to understand.
The music? Amazing. Perfect. You can feel the place all around you if you just close your eyes and listen to it ^^

reviewText:
The Last Remnant. JRPG ala final fantasy buatan square enix yang diport untuk xbox360 dan PC windows. Sebelum Final Fantasy XIII dirilis untuk PC, mungkin The Last Remnant adalah satu-satunya JRPG dengan grafis modern di PC.

Cerita (7/10)
Biarpun mungkin terlihat sederhana, namun cerita TLR sebenarnya cukup rumit bila kita memainkan semua side quest yang diberikan. Seperti asal usul suatu tempat dan runtuhnya kerajaan kuno. Semuanya diberikan sepotong-sepotong. Kalau kita hanya mengikuti alur cerita mungkin akan terasa banyak lubang di cerita ini.

Gameplay (8/10)
Gameplay TLR sangat unik. Tidak hanya 3-4 karakter yang bisa jadi anggota party kita tapi sampai 18 karakter! Eksekusinya cukup mudah berdasarkan union yang terdiri hingga 5 karakter. Kita bisa mengelompokkan union mana yang melakukan combat art (serangan fisik), mystic art (serangan mystic) support atau healing. Penggunaan formasi juga berpengaruh dalam menghadapi boss tertentu.

Grafis (4/10)
SIsi grafis cukup menyedihkan. Dunia dalam TLR sebenarnya sangat indah dan detail, sayang sekali penggunaan Unreal Engine tidak maksimal. Hal paling menyedihkan adalah saat pindah scene ada jeda 2-3 detik untuk loading texture. Sangat menyedihkan.........

reviewText:
An awesome JRPG! -- 9.5/10

I think most of the reviews don't do justice to this game. It has a different (and maybe difficult at the beginning) battle system, but once you learn, you will undertand how good and complex it is. The story is ok and you cannot fully control the game mechanics, for example some of your characters may choose an unwanted path and craft/equip weapons that will change the Union strategy. But this is a JRPG that tried to innovate, and in my opinion, it succeeded!
Well, I had lots of fun playing this version and the console version(Which is a bad version, the PC port is way superior).

Oh yeah, and I loved the soundtrack. It fit perfectly for epic battles or just have a walk in the town :)

Don't try to use a Final Fantasy measure for a game that is not even trying to be a Final Fantasy.

With a very current gaming pc running a GTX590 this game has run fantastic on windows7.I have not had one issue at all after about 90 hrs of gameplay.

Even more surprising was realising how deep the game is.The game wiki is over 3000 pages now.

I recommend people look at the wiki to get an idea of the game.

Using a Xbox compatble pad makes playing this much easier  especially with timing crits.

reviewText:
The last remnant is a great RPG and has many great quirks about it.

First thing the bad points
.Difficult to ever determine how much xp to level up
.HP is never fair compared to some of the enemies
.Getting new equipement is a massive chore
.Companions equipment causes you to do a million chores including grinding
.Story is difficult to keep up with because cut scenes are so far apart
.Some bosses become ridiculously difficult near the end

Good Points
.Turn based combat, so room to think
.graphics aren't bad
.Classic RPG style
.Fully customizable party
.Special moves are awesome
.Easy to save progress
.Easily worth it when it's on sale

Hope this helps :)

reviewText: I've heard a lot of good about this game and it was alright up until now. This game feels impossible to beat and I'm not far into the game at all. One heals to full health, the other attacks to do something productive(don't want 2 heals when the first gives you full health, right?). This works for 2-3 turns but I always end up dying. Perhaps I could grind it and hope I get a really lucky streak of receiving low damage or something but come on, that's bad game design.

reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a unique title.  It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing.  The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right?  Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.

What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay.  When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before.  What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES.  Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads.  This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not.  This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.

This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while.  The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch.  If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.
