reviewText:
The Last Remnant is a unique title.  It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing.  The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right?  Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.

What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay.  When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before.  What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES.  Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads.  This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not.  This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.

This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while.  The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch.  If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.

reviewText:
+ Interesting battle system
+ Sufficient amount of content
+ Stunning world designs
+ Runs smoothly enough

- Character models could've been better
- Can't manually customize characters
^ They will use whatever spare gear you have when they decide they want to trade, so not recommended at all to craft and enhance items specifically for them
^ Getting them to learn specific arts is terribly complicated as there's no set way to do so
^ Possibly good character that appear later on will be awfully weak compared to the player's battle rank
- Slight delay on world rendering after entering a new area
- Story and characters aren't interesting
- Some annoying graphical glitches

Verditc: It's a fun game. Not polished enough for Square Enix standards, but with an engaging battle system and quite enough content to keep the player hooked.

reviewText:
It pains me to write this review. I am a big fan of square enix and of the games produced by them. When I saw this title on steam, i thought 'ah, cool. An rpg by one of my favorite video game companies.'

After playing for about two hours, my initial reaction was completely turned around. While the game does have 3d animation comparable to the time it was produced, the remainder of the game is sub-par from what I have seen of other titles by square enix.

The battle system is extremely boring and repetative. While it is easy to learn, it doesn't make sense. Instead of controlling a single character or issuing commands to multiple characters, you issue orders to squads, or unions" as they are called in the game. And the types of commands are limited to the circumstances of the battle

reviewText:
It's Final Fantasy; same gameplay, same mechanics, same character design and a typical Final Fantasy storyline. If you like Final Fantasy, then you will probably like this.

As is typical for Final Fantasy games, all in-game controls are shown as controller buttons rather than as mouse or keyboard buttons. This game was meant to be played with a controller. Not being able to just click on what I want to do and having to scroll through options one at a time instead is too much for me to bear, but I suspect this type of control is fine to those who find Final Fantasy games enjoyable in the first place.

There are a lot of cutscenes and I don't think they can be skipped (at least I couldn't figure out a way to do so). If you aren't into the story, then the cutscenes could be a chore for you. They were for me, so I won't be returning to the game.

The first hour (or however much I played) is the funniest thing I've seen in ages. I got it in a bundle, so I don't really have complaints but this is pretty incredible. I guess it's a console port because you can't use your mouse for anything, which makes changing the settings a huge pain in the ♥♥♥ when you load up the game. The voice acting is hysterical, and the horrific cat general seems to change actors randomly. The main character looks a bit like teary-eyed Toby Miguire and has flesh-coloured eyes to my disgust.

I'm not really sure what's going on in the game story wise because the main character tells his story to one NPC, and suddenly every NPC knows of his sister's disappearance.

Even though I don't recommend the game, this kind of writing has to be experienced at some point in your life.

reviewText: The Last Remant is a game made by the well known Square Enix group, which is the main reason i purchaced it (despite the low rating). After a little bit of messing around here and there with the large array of video settings, I stepped off into the game and realized quickly that it was just another generic japanese rpg. Some overpowered guy has caputred some innocent girl and you (being the brother) must go rescue her. Despite the generic storyline, the gameplay is not bad if you like cluttered screens. A good 80% of the screen is filled with some sort of box telling you something (during combat). The tactical perspectives of the game (such as being able to flank someone in mid-combat for a boost to moral and etc) makes for great mechanics, however it is drowned out by not feeling the true immersion of a square enix title. I wouldn't recommend buying this game unless you do not mind generic storyline, low immersion, high clutterence titles.

reviewText:
I often equate this game to the JRPG equivalent of a bad B-movie, which can be considered both a good and a bad thing, depending on what you’re expecting going in.

Between the thin story and terrible voice acting just getting through the first few cut-scenes will likely be enough to push most players away from the game entirely. That having been said, if you do decide to give the game a shot, the terrible acting does let up a bit after you get about 10 hours into the main quest side of the game, and the story starts to pick up a bit even if it still follows many of the standard JRPG clichés.

Gameplay-wise, The Last Remnant is very ‘hands-off’. The party system mechanics are actually rather interesting, allowing you to recruit members to add to your party and split them up into groups for combat, but it falls short due to the fact that you have no control over those recruits equipment or skills. Gaining new skills requires that a previous skill in the same ‘tree’ is used in combat to give a chance for a new skill to be learned or an old one to be upgraded but even that is left up to a modicum of randomness, unfortunately making the entire system an endeavor of patience and repetition.

The battle system is likely where you will either learn to love the game despite itself or simply hate it enough to give up entirely. To put it simply, you have almost no control whatsoever. Instead you are given a series of choices based on various factors, such as party/enemy levels, active party skills, party/enemy/ally HP, etc. It is possible to lean the options in a certain direction by disabling non-useful abilities before entering combat so that they are not available as a choice, but even then you may still get turns where your mage-only group is given only physically offensive options.

Once you get far enough to have 3 groups battles become a bit easier to handle. If you manage to stick around long enough to get to 4 groups, however, the combat system starts to shine a bit, adding in more potential tactics and a better balance for the battles. It’s really at this point that both the gameplay and the story start to pick up and become more fluid all around.

I personally have enjoyed my time playing The Last Remnant, but I went into it fully expecting it to be severely lacking in some areas, and as such will be the first to admit that it is not for everyone. It takes a long time to actually get to the fun parts of the game, but once you’re there it’s… well, fun.

It’s not epic or life changing, but if you want to play a JRPG that’s a bit different and have the patience to make this one work, then keep a look-out for when it goes on sale and give it a shot. Otherwise, you will most likely be better off passing this one up.

reviewText:
I picked this up as a part of a bundle, expecting nothing much and it was worse off than i thought. The first hours of the game have you in a tutorial where you just follow commands. After I was done with that and finally got control of my own units, i spent about an hour grinding cause the game kinda didn't tell me how to trigger the next flag. The story is bland as oatmeal, with some voiceovers being really cringeworthy.

But then to the meat of the game, the combat. Much to the credit of the game, they are trying something new, instead of controlling single characters actions you now control a group of characters (called a Union). The combat system is simple enough with a leveling system even simpler, use stuff and it eventually levels up. Although leveling up doesn't help you much since the game heavily relies on numbers and RNG, what those numbers might be I couldn't tell you, since the game in no way explains it. RNG is also a big factor, when against the same mob (as in reloading a save and actually fighting the same mob) the outcome of the first round was wildly different, ranging from killing a enemy union without getting hit to myself being one-shotted, this against exactly the same mob.

The game looks pretty enough (if you can overlook som glitchy graphics) although most of the enviroments seems to be quite boring. The dungeons throws nonsense mechanics at you for no reason at all *door shuts down and you get to fight the same mobs you've been chomping like tic-tacs to get there*. In another dungeon there is a slow-down fog, it does nothing exept slow you down, so instead of wasting 5 seconds running down an empty hallway, you now get to enjoy the same empty hallway for a minute.

All in all, the game reminds me alot of FFX, if you take away intresting scenes, combat and story.

reviewText: My very minimal time with the game will tell you that I did not like it very much. reviewText: If you can look past the cheesy as hell JRPG writing, the unskippable cutscenes that drags on forever (which you get to see twice or more if you lose), the story you couldn't care less for, the grindy turn based JRPG find-the-rare-drop gameplay, the convoluted skill system, the least lively-looking cities you've ever seen and if you enjoy where-the-hell-do-I-go-now games in general, you'll be happy to know there is a playable race that looks like midget humanoid frogs with Dachshund ears. reviewText:
The game tries so hard to be a squd-based strategic rpg. An nearly gets it done at least halfway.

Which basically means that the base system is good - you can find / hire new units, put them in a squad together and then give them positions in different formations depending on their function. You can even costumize the different units pretty well, in regards of abilities and equipment. In combat you then choose overall orders like attack enemy with magic / physical abilites" etc. Overall the system is a bit similar to Fire Emblem.

But that is where the bad stuff happens. Actually the game never bothers to tell you anything. Not about how the specialization
date: itemization and development of units works. Not even what the different orders for the combat do. That is where the game just becomes a bad joke. At some point I got three options for hitting the enemies with physical abilities. All costing the same amount of ability points
recommended: but I had no clue what order makes what unit use which ability.\nFor a game that wants you to micro so much of the units
hoursPlayed: their equipment and their skills
voteText: you have practicall NO controll over their behaviour in combat.\nAnother example: At some point I decided to do a pure healer squad for backing my fighters up
helpfulPercent: since they got ganged by AoE-attacks during a hard fight. So I put a few magic users in a squad
votesHelpful: told them to only use their healing abilities and let them wait in the background to heal the others. Which was utterly useless. Only like every 3 rounds I got the option to heal the other squad
votesTotal: which was pretty dead at that point. BUT was I happy to notice that my healers had the possibily to smach the dragons skill in with their puny staffs.\nAlso
votesFunny: of course you don't know what enemies you fight before you encounter them. So in the same area there can be a group of 2 units which you can one-hit. Then the next encounter is a disguised mini-boss
commentsCount: who summons elite squads every round and hit all your squads every time it attacks. No jokes
column16: those monsters stood right next to each other.\n\nAlso I can and will not give thumbs up for a game that just continues to crash when you attempt to change the graphic options. That is just flat out ridiculous."

reviewText:
This game... I really can not understand how this game could get so many positive reviews. It failes at so many levels. First of all it features the most annoying male protagonist ever. And that really isn't a good start for a game when the character you start the game with is causing you pain just listening to him.

It also features a horribly random combat system. Not just is the order in which characters and enemies got to take an action random. Also the actions a character has available at his turn are down to randomness. You desperately need to heal? Well, you can only pray that in the next turn the game gives you the option to heal as one of the available actions.

I lost a lot of fights not because of doing anything wrong, but simply because the random number generator decided to not give me the option to heal when I would have needed it. Terrible design.

Another prime example of terrible design would be the leveling system. It's probably the most counter-intuitive leveling system ever featured in an RPG. Rule number 1: the less you fight the easier the game is. Getting a higher battle rank in this game is NOT a good thing. It will make basically all encounters harder up to the point that some become outright frustrating thanks to the randomness of the combat system.

The easiest way to play this game is to just run through the areas and avoid fighting as much as possible...


I never finished the game. The combination of meh story, painful main character, and the terribly random combat system extinguished my interest in completing the game fairly quickly.

I really can not recommend this game to anyone. Both gameplay and story fail to deliver.

reviewText:
When the words Square Enix and RPG go together great things happen, unfortunately The Last Remnant is proof that even the best in the business can get it wrong.  Despite solid potential in the form of an excellent storyline and brilliant characters, the game is let down by an awqward progression system and a difficulty curve that is so inconsistent, a visual representation would look like a bowl of frustrated spaghetti.

The Last Remnant follows an intriguing storyline, vividly brought to life through brilliant character acting and the very best quality voice acting.  The excellent production allows the player to really connect with the characters and experience the feels of story to the fullest.  Unfortunately, the ridiculous jumps in difficulty negate this by forcing the player to spend great lengths of time struggling to progress, ultimately destroying the rhythm of the story.  Impossible chain boss fights are sudden and deny the player any chance for recuperation, so much so that even multiple save files will not save you (hue hue) from hours of punishment.  Add to this the long, arduous random battles which can accumulate into hours of necessary grinding to rectify the tardy and deceptive progression system known as 'battle rank' and any enjoyment quickly fizzles away.

The main point of interest in The Last Remnant is the battle system.  The player controls several parties of characters in the form of a turn based strategy with real time combat elements.  This is not particularly effective as the player is limited to a pre-determined set of attacks depending on the situation, inevitably replacing strategy with luck.  The real time combat elements have been cleverly integrated to sway the tide of battle if executed correctly and play a major role in determining the outcome of each fight.  Outside of battle the gameplay is fairly limited in terms of exploration and despite there being plentiful completionist content and a strangely addictive appeal, the majority is simply empty dialogue followed by a re-run of previously visited dungeons.

Overall, The Last Remnant shows promise but quickly succumbs to its flaws which hinder the game from ever competing on the same level as it's better known stablemates.  If you are an RPG enthusiast with a high tolerance for frustration then you may be able to enjoy The Last Remnant.  If not, you would be better off looking elsewhere.

3 subligars out of 5.

reviewText: Fun game but unoptimized :\n\nI was mid playing the game and minimized and walked away for a good 10 minutes. When I came back my computer was literally unusable because it had reached 100% memory usuage. After more playing around I realized that if you minimize the game your Non-paged pool" memory climbs at a rate of 10mb per second. After more playing around I also realized in non rendered zones it goes up by 2-3 mb per second
date: these are things such as the title screen and places like city maps and the world map
recommended: however in open areas that you can walk in the non paged pool does not change. All in all I have realized this game is not the most optomized thing seeing these pretty large memory leaks that do not stop until 100% memory usage.\n\nThat being said I enjoy the game
hoursPlayed: it is just issues like these may change how you feel about a game and possibly impact your decision on buying it."

reviewText:
I tried playing this game, and apparently it's literally unplayable with Mouse and Keyboard. I couldn't even start the first real encounter because apparently the Right and Left Triggers aren't even ♥♥♥♥ing bound to anything on the keyboard or mouse. I sat there for a good minute trying every button on the entire keyboard, and none of them worked.

So here's an even further list of beefs:
> No rebindable keys
> Extremely intrusive Depth of Field which hides all details except for what's in the dead center of the screen, and even then it's extremely aggressive use means you can only see parts of whatever character is in focus
> No graphics settings
> Framerate caps in combat
> Voice acting sounds like it was recorded in a bathroom. To test this, I went into my bathroom and attempted to mimick the voices of the few characters I heard. No surprise, I sounded exactly like the characters.
> Unskippable cutscenes
> Completely impossible to play without a gamepad

reviewText: Oh dear god.  I thought RPG games on PC were supposed to have interaction, where you felt like you were actually playing the game and had some control over events.  Not this game.  It's a Japanese style RPG, which means lots of waffle and pretty graphics, but minimal input from the player.  If I really wanted this kind of thing, I'd put a DVD on, rather than this.  If you like turn-based battles, nice animation, and loooooooooooooong cut-scenes that you can't skip, please buy this game.  Otherwise, don't.

reviewText: Weak visuals, bland music, poor writing, and an almost entirely unexplained mess of a battle system make The Last remnant nothing more than a chore to play. The areas of the world are small and linear, and you will find yourself travelling back to them time after time. The UI in battle is both confusing and intrusive; the UI outside of battle is little better. The story is mildly interesting but doesn't provide enough of an incentive to suffer through the rest of the game.\n\nThere's a reason The Last remnant is a bargain-bin title; don't waste your money when there are far better titles available.

reviewText:
This game isn't even worth the ♥♥♥♥ing 9 dollars it costs...you try to build a party at a guild...then you go into a certain map, and that party is NO WHERE TO BE FOUND! So you take on these stupid quests with townsfolk...you end up in a dungeon with said townsfolk...with your party NO WHERE TO BE FOUND. Beating side quests seems impossible. Where did my ♥♥♥♥ing party go once I assigned them at a guild? WHERE?! Is this one of those games you have to grind for hours in a low level area to be able to take on side quests? I mean where is my ♥♥♥♥ing party!? I assigned them at a guild! WHY AREN'T THE IN MY PARTY?!

Don't play this. It's only a few years old but the graphics seem circa 2001...there is only voice acting during cut scenes...the rest you have to READ! Imagine, an xbox360 game where you have to read the ♥♥♥♥ing quest dialogue...pathetic.

Edit: I found out how to take the party you create into a map...but that didn't make the experience much better...this game requires old school exp grinding to make it anywhere. I find myeslf dying from one group of regular monsters...despite fully understanding the combat system. It's just a really unbalnced game. I ground for hours to beat ONE rare boss mob in an early cave area. Still impossible to beat it. I understand the combat....my characters are well leveled. This game got very good reviews when it was first released...I have a feeling the company that made this game paid handsomely to get these positive reviews...something big companies are known to do.


Dated graphics for a 2009 release, minimal voice acting...strange unbalanced combat system...zero phsycis, Completely linear, Trite, cliche story...forgetable characters, mandatory exp grinding and a whole host of other problems. Androgenous heroes. ♥♥♥♥, the females in this game look more manly than the males...I don't need a ♥♥♥♥ing lesson in androgeny. Square Enix, has lost their luster...and then some. When the company was Squaresoft...they were shining. This game is a clear example of how Squaresoft sold out. Don't believe me? Pay the 9 dollars yourself and find out.

reviewText: Not your typical JRPG but is recommended for the fans of the genre if you're looking to play a JRPG from a whole new perspective. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
EPIC COMBAT SYSTEM: you don't control just one party, you control several parties at once on a battlefied against multiple groups of enemies. Gone is the traditional micro of turn-based combat; instead you direct each group to focus on magic or combat techniques and which enemy groups to engage - and then watch as both forces charge towards each other, resulting in interceptions, flanking, and morale swings. Late-game, the respawning normal monster combats become tedious, but the boss battles only get more EPIC.
Gorgeous visuals: I was once stuck on a quest wandering around a giant desert for 2hrs or so - and I didn't care, because the sand dunes in every direction just looked so pretty.
Immersive storyline of the kind SquareEnix is known for. Every character has a story.
The only thing I would gripe about is the expensive crafting system. At least your party members will just ask you for any components you have that they could use - you don't micro their equipment upgrades, either.

reviewText: This game could quite easily be called The Lost Final Fantasy". It Shares a lot of similarities to final fantasy 12
date: it builds on and expands the freedom of exploration
hoursPlayed: monster hunting system and combat system.\n\nThe story you will either like it or you wont. I liked the overall story but I really didnt like a couple of the main characters
voteText: enough to skip cutscenes with them. a bit like Hope in FF13.\n\nThe combat takes things to a completely new level. You start out with your standard 2-3 person party to learn the ropes with and progress naturally over the course of the game to 18 party members spead over up to 5 squads. Thankfully its turn based so you can plan out your attacks. Although you dont see it
helpfulPercent: there is an underlying battle grid that the fights take place on. The relative positions of you and your enemy play the main role in determining what attack/skill options you have available
votesHelpful: which get learnt over time. You can either take it at face value and charge in
votesTotal: or learn the intricacies to take full control of the battles and play at a tactical level.\n\nCharacter progression has been done very well
votesFunny: most of the micromanagement has been taken out
commentsCount: instead of having to craft/individually gear 18+ party members they just chime in when they want something. Skill progression is handled equally well on the PC version
column16: you can either direct them in a specific combat direction or you can allow them to develop organically by enabling/disabling skill trees
column17:
which also determines their overall class.

overall i'd give it:
6/10 story
9/10 battle system
8/10 character development
8/10 game world

If your an avid final fantasy fan (at least up till 12) this game needs to be in your collection."

reviewText:
It's probably worth my while mentioning the reason I first purchased this game (on Xbox, originally): some of the best slash writers in my reading list were writing really interesting stuff about the characters, and I wanted to get the original context.

Basically, this game is best played for the story and the interplay between the characters.  The animation, frankly, is as clunky as all get-out - it's best played after playing something like Final Fantasy VII or VIII (the original PS versions if you can get them) as something of a palate cleanser if you're a real graphics junkie (or you could go the whole hog and just play Angband or a similar text-based RPG as a starter).  The battle system is different - it's turn-based (as with the Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest series), but instead of making decisions about each individual fighter's actions, you're issuing commands to groups of fighters (and they will perform their actions based on your command).  You don't get access to every possible command - instead, you're choosing from a limited list - between six to eight options most of the time, narrowing down to about two or three when things get really nasty.  If you're a gameplay or a graphics fan, this probably isn't the game for you.

If, like me, you're interested in story and worldbuilding, however, this game is *brilliant*.  The world is complex and well-realised, and it's fun to be sitting down and figuring out the back-story and the background politics.  The story is fascinating, and if you're a slash fan, it is a hoot how slashtastic the interaction between Rush and David (pronounced Dah-veed) turns out to be at times - and the slashtastic moments start very early on in the game.  The art is marvellously detailed, the backgrounds are glorious, and the characters are wonderfully created.  In many ways, I get the sense they spent so much time and effort on creating the story and the artwork that when it came time to add the animation and the gameplay, they'd almost run through the budget.  This resulted in very unrealistic movement (it's almost as though their animation models were puppets on strings - it is *very* Thunderbirds movement at times) and a lot of skimped details in the FMV scenes (the one which sticks in my head is one scene where Rush is sitting on a bed... and because the bed isn't animated at all, it stays a rigid rectangular shape.  All I could think is that has to be hell on the back").

It's almost a pity
recommended: they didn't put the same amount of time and effort into animating their artwork that they did into crafting it.  The voice actors do their best (although if you're familiar with British accents at all

reviewText:
It's probably worth my while mentioning the reason I first purchased this game (on Xbox, originally): some of the best slash writers in my reading list were writing really interesting stuff about the characters, and I wanted to get the original context.

Basically, this game is best played for the story and the interplay between the characters.  The animation, frankly, is as clunky as all get-out - it's best played after playing something like Final Fantasy VII or VIII (the original PS versions if you can get them) as something of a palate cleanser if you're a real graphics junkie (or you could go the whole hog and just play Angband or a similar text-based RPG as a starter).  The battle system is different - it's turn-based (as with the Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest series), but instead of making decisions about each individual fighter's actions, you're issuing commands to groups of fighters (and they will perform their actions based on your command).  You don't get access to every possible command - instead, you're choosing from a limited list - between six to eight options most of the time, narrowing down to about two or three when things get really nasty.  If you're a gameplay or a graphics fan, this probably isn't the game for you.

If, like me, you're interested in story and worldbuilding, however, this game is *brilliant*.  The world is complex and well-realised, and it's fun to be sitting down and figuring out the back-story and the background politics.  The story is fascinating, and if you're a slash fan, it is a hoot how slashtastic the interaction between Rush and David (pronounced Dah-veed) turns out to be at times - and the slashtastic moments start very early on in the game.  The art is marvellously detailed, the backgrounds are glorious, and the characters are wonderfully created.  In many ways, I get the sense they spent so much time and effort on creating the story and the artwork that when it came time to add the animation and the gameplay, they'd almost run through the budget.  This resulted in very unrealistic movement (it's almost as though their animation models were puppets on strings - it is *very* Thunderbirds movement at times) and a lot of skimped details in the FMV scenes (the one which sticks in my head is one scene where Rush is sitting on a bed... and because the bed isn't animated at all, it stays a rigid rectangular shape.  All I could think is that has to be hell on the back").

It's almost a pity
recommended: they didn't put the same amount of time and effort into animating their artwork that they did into crafting it.  The voice actors do their best (although if you're familiar with British accents at all
hoursPlayed: you'll notice Lord David's accent keeps sneaking off toward Sarf Lunnon when he isn't watching) but really

reviewText:
EPIC COMBAT SYSTEM: you don't control just one party, you control several parties at once on a battlefied against multiple groups of enemies. Gone is the traditional micro of turn-based combat; instead you direct each group to focus on magic or combat techniques and which enemy groups to engage - and then watch as both forces charge towards each other, resulting in interceptions, flanking, and morale swings. Late-game, the respawning normal monster combats become tedious, but the boss battles only get more EPIC.
Gorgeous visuals: I was once stuck on a quest wandering around a giant desert for 2hrs or so - and I didn't care, because the sand dunes in every direction just looked so pretty.
Immersive storyline of the kind SquareEnix is known for. Every character has a story.
The only thing I would gripe about is the expensive crafting system. At least your party members will just ask you for any components you have that they could use - you don't micro their equipment upgrades, either.

reviewText: Incredible. Absolutely incredible. The Last Remnant is unlike any other RPG i've ever played. Characters grow stronger through battle like most RPGs, but instead of EXP, the individual stats of a character will increase through battle, kind of like a fixed version of FFII. What I really thought was unique in the game was how the party is formed. Units on the battlefield are represented by groups. You assign individual characters to act as one, and then you can assign a formation to that group which can improve a variety of combat skills. I was lucky enough to get this during the Steam Summer Sale for only $2. And let me say, it was the best $2 I have ever, and will spend in my entire life. The only downside is that the game spikes in difficulty sometimes, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I don't think it's good either. Overall, this game is amazing and deserves a lot more recognition than it already has.

reviewText:
A refreshing change in gameplay. Although the game does start slow and somewhat hard, it progresses to be on a perfect pace on gameplay with the story progressing on an equal scale, making for a perfect blend of a gaming experience.

The gameplay mechanics is based off of randomly generated moves based on what you already know, and is changed based upon who you target. Your playable characters are grouped into parties that will be affected in different ways depending on who is in it. What affects the group? In general, the type of combat preference your characters have, the formation you have the group in (You'll see soon enough in the game once you can recruit multiple members into your parties), and finally how many people are in a party. You can have multiple parties.

Speaking of the story specifically, it is well written, but is by no means a master piece, but as I had said, the story the game brings is fulfulling and is more than enough to please you.

Gameplay specifically, as I had previously mentioned, this game starts out slow and somewhat hard. Grinding is not exactly mandatory in this game, but is somewhat appreciated if you refuse to fight boss battles over and over. The game really wants boss battles in this game to live up to it's name. And in the beginning of the game, boss battles are excepionally harder than most fights you will encounter.

Also, a REALLY IMPORTANT note to make, all boss battles are preceded by a cutscene of varying length, usually more than a minute or more in length. This is important to mention because CUTSCENES ARE UNSKIPPABLE, meaning that if you fail a boss battle, you will have to suffer watching the same cutscene over and over. Hence, grinding is somewhat a real recommendation early on in the game. If you are finding yourself in this loop of a boss battle failing, I reccomend going back and grinding a level or two and consider upgrading your equipment and changing your parties' formations. Also, shift tab is reccomended if you can't stand the cutscenes. This is probably the only problem you will have with this game.
^Tl;dr: Grind if you hate time passing you by without making progress.

Also, another note worth mentioning is that this game has a New Game+, which means that after you beat the game, you can play through it again retaining all your arts you learned as well as components you use to make items in the game.
Although if you plan to play New Game+, you should SPLIT ALL UNNEEDED ITEMS before the final boss. You lose everything in material things but components, you even lose your gold.

*Any gold you get in New Game+'s start is based on how many quests you did.


Although, a perfect thing to be mentioned is that this game might not be for everyone. But with everything in mind, this game is by all means a decent thing to buy, especially consideing its low cost on steam.



*Can skip cutscenes with an xbox controller, only
Also, a note worth mentioning, this game is fully xbox controller compatible, and the game is automatically set to think you are playing with an xbox controller.
Change the controls first thing you get into the game, unless you want to be forced to by invonvenience


^^^^^^^^^ TL;DR: I RECCOMEND THIS GAME, GRIND IF HARD. GAME IS STILL GOOD.

reviewText:
It seems that SquareEnix tries to re-live the thriumph of its golden era but not so succesfully i suppose. Here is The Last Remnant a jrpg with turn based battles that feature some RTS elements. More in depth we have:

GAMEPLAY:

In TLR you get to control a youth named Rush. You venture in 3D invironments in towns and dungeons while the city and wolrd maps are simple images (kinda .. Naaaaahh" to me). The enemies are visible on the screen and you can ambush them avoid them or get ambushed (you dont wanna do that). Well here comes the sad part! The battle system thought it seems quite promising it ends to be very boring one sided and soooo automated! Well its seems like the developers would like to make it extremely simple yet strangely difficult to win a battle. What do i mean? Here is the thing. When you enter the battle there is no option of escape!! The player has to choose between some automated commands like "attack"
date:
or "back em up" or "attack with combat arts". Seriously? All you have to be careful about is not to get flanked (amonst enemies) and all is great! i mean come on?! what happened to equipping magic or using items manually and stuff like that!? Many will say that TLR differs cos it is more like strategy when it comes to the battle part but i disagree! Even if it is that way its quite noobish! Unfortunately gameplay isnt its strong part!

PLOT:

The plot is quite classic yet very enjoyable with the classic fantasy world and its kingdoms. In the first intro we see Rush rushing into a battlefield while he searches for his freshly kidnapped sister! i wont do any more spoilers. Play it yourselves!

MUSIC:

The music part is one of its strong points i guess where its plave has its own music. It is very pompous and magnificent at parts and get you quite well in the mood

GRAPHICS:

Graphics are wuite detailed and "clean" with lots of colors and drawn and designed with creativity and talent! The only thing is that sometimes it gives me the impression that there is so much symmetry especially in towns!

OVERALL:

In general terms TLR is a game worthy of your time and money that every jrpg games must at least once experience!"

reviewText: I'd never heard of this before, but it's pretty great. You know how every time a new console launches, developers show off games with huge epic battles? This is the Square Enix take on that trope. It's a Final-Fantasy-esque affair where instead of a party of four, you merrily traipse around with a small army.\n\nIt features the most complicated, in-depth, opaque menu battle system I've ever seen. Things start off a little slow, the wiki is required reading, and the story doesn't seem to be anything special. But squad management and battles are a lot of fun. If you want a classic style JRPG with actually interesting gameplay, this is it. It goes ridiculously cheap on a regular basis, so maybe wait a couple weeks for a sale.

reviewText:
TLR is even better than I hoped.

Battle mechanics:
Makes you feel like a commander in the battelfield rather than the main character of a story, which is kinda refreshing and truth be told not that different from traditional RPG battle systems, since you select attack and see if you hit, miss, or get a critical hit, good thing that in TLR criticals(offensive and defensive) depend on you so you don't just sit back and watch the battles.

Class system:
It's both a good and a bad thing, is so huge that you'll be surprised, I was at least. but there's no reliable way to track progress and predict it accurately.

Your main character can become whatever you want him to be which is always great, using whatever weapon you want which is a bonus, giving him different attacks depending on what you choose which is unusual, and feeling like he is trully becoming proficient instead of just a regular guy learning skills, what is there not to love about that?

The world itself I find it lacking, you can visit few places. but even on the city itself what you see, find or the people you talk to is too limited.

Side quests feel dull, specially when you accept and get teleported in and out, it feels wrong to me not going myself to do something I said I would, and not having a record of things that need doing in my main menu is annoying.

All in all it's a great game, love the visuals, the voice acting is great.

reviewText:
It seems that SquareEnix tries to re-live the thriumph of its golden era but not so succesfully i suppose. Here is The Last Remnant a jrpg with turn based battles that feature some RTS elements. More in depth we have:

GAMEPLAY:

In TLR you get to control a youth named Rush. You venture in 3D invironments in towns and dungeons while the city and wolrd maps are simple images (kinda .. Naaaaahh" to me). The enemies are visible on the screen and you can ambush them avoid them or get ambushed (you dont wanna do that). Well here comes the sad part! The battle system thought it seems quite promising it ends to be very boring one sided and soooo automated! Well its seems like the developers would like to make it extremely simple yet strangely difficult to win a battle. What do i mean? Here is the thing. When you enter the battle there is no option of escape!! The player has to choose between some automated commands like "attack"
date:
or "back em up" or "attack with combat arts". Seriously? All you have to be careful about is not to get flanked (amonst enemies) and all is great! i mean come on?! what happened to equipping magic or using items manually and stuff like that!? Many will say that TLR differs cos it is more like strategy when it comes to the battle part but i disagree! Even if it is that way its quite noobish! Unfortunately gameplay isnt its strong part!

PLOT:

The plot is quite classic yet very enjoyable with the classic fantasy world and its kingdoms. In the first intro we see Rush rushing into a battlefield while he searches for his freshly kidnapped sister! i wont do any more spoilers. Play it yourselves!

MUSIC:

The music part is one of its strong points i guess where its plave has its own music. It is very pompous and magnificent at parts and get you quite well in the mood

GRAPHICS:

Graphics are wuite detailed and "clean" with lots of colors and drawn and designed with creativity and talent! The only thing is that sometimes it gives me the impression that there is so much symmetry especially in towns!

OVERALL:

In general terms TLR is a game worthy of your time and money that every jrpg games must at least once experience!"

reviewText: Incredible. Absolutely incredible. The Last Remnant is unlike any other RPG i've ever played. Characters grow stronger through battle like most RPGs, but instead of EXP, the individual stats of a character will increase through battle, kind of like a fixed version of FFII. What I really thought was unique in the game was how the party is formed. Units on the battlefield are represented by groups. You assign individual characters to act as one, and then you can assign a formation to that group which can improve a variety of combat skills. I was lucky enough to get this during the Steam Summer Sale for only $2. And let me say, it was the best $2 I have ever, and will spend in my entire life. The only downside is that the game spikes in difficulty sometimes, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I don't think it's good either. Overall, this game is amazing and deserves a lot more recognition than it already has.

reviewText:
This one of the bunch of RPG's from the previous gen that I always regretted not getting into,  and thankfully have remedied that. I know the console version suffered from a few technical hiccups but the PC version as of 2015 runs flawlessly under the highest settings and in 2k resolution. With that out of the way, the game:

Sound design is classic Squenix in that there is plenty of orchestral and rock riffs to be had during battle and world traversal and the sound FX and voice overs are clean and punchy even output @ 48khz. (havent tried the higher sample rates)

Graphics, if run with the aforementioned settings are crisp & detailed with no stutter what-so-ever with modern hardware (gtx 860m). While overall, nothing truly eye popping given the rpg's age they do look noticably better than the console release.

In summary, with this games unique combat mechanics (solid tutorial included for the first few hours), interesting and funny characters as well as solid voice acting coupled with Squenix's classic scripting rpg fans have a sleeper on their hands that should appeal to a wide audience.

reviewText: I've seen a lot of dislike for this game, but in my opinion it was a pretty fantastic game. The Last Remnant had a great story line, and a unique and interested battle system. The idea of squads instead of individual units is something that added the feel of actually controlling a small force instead of just a party of adventurers. And the morale system, while tricky and can work against you, led to shifts in battle in the same way they might happen in real life. Overall it was a lot of fun to play, even if the PC version was harder than the Xbox hard version.

reviewText:
I'm sad that this game didn't get the love it deserved at release, to few buyers to continue the series. But it might change if gets viral. 10$ this is a damn ripoff, deserves way more like when I paid 49$ around release.

Bought it around 2010 and my PC could barely handle it at max. Graphically still amazing to this day, and you can even get a EMB Mod to enhance it even more.

Story - Decent, but that's not what you're here for.
- Lovely visuals, animation and bosses

Gameplay - The reason it works, it's new and when you finally get the hang of it. The time flies owning dragons.
- Amazing quantity of weapons, read the cfg edit on google to toogle on so you can equit any weapon on AI.
- So many hidden quest, characters, items and formations to unlock.
- Hire any mercenary's and level them up, and you decide whoever you want to use throughout the game.
- Re-playable and it rewards you!
- Can be hard for the new to RPG's if you don't know what you're doing. Google is your friend here.

Hours of hours and even if you kill the last boss it's not near complete, this game feels like it could never end.
Definently try it out, and give it more than a few hours.

PS:PSSS - Turn on Automatic save in options right away, my pc back in the day crashed when I was far in the story. Glad I didn't give up, but it kinda drained my moral. Funny thing I got a better start from doing it over, and better combat/spells.

reviewText:
It's a fairly good game, entertaining enough so far. It seems to have fairly decent depth, the world seems moderately vibrant, the combat is complex (perhaps a tad much) and the animations and graphics are solid.

There's two big gripes I have with this game, one being a lack of aesthetically impactful design in terms of music. The music is bland and barely memorable. Not much more to be said for it.

The other gripe is that the game is a tremendously lazy port, to the point where all instructions show an Xbox controller button rather than a keyboard key. Rewriting the tutorials would've done wonders, but instead, players are forced to look up and perhaps even jot down all the important keys. This is particularly painful with the battle mechanism of critical calls, something akin to the action commands from Mario & Luigi and Paper Mario. The screen will show the A, B, Y and X buttons or the Right Trigger, and you're supposed to figure out what to press without any appropriate visual cue. (In case you're interested, it's the arrow keys for the A, B, Y and X buttons, and space bar for the Right Trigger)

Other than that, the game seems rather promising and I hope it will continue to deliver.

reviewText: JRPGs were a holy grail of console gaming in the 8 and 16 bit days. In the 32, there were classics of the genre like Eternal Arcadia, Sakura Wars and Grandia II. Oh, no Final Fantasy? Haven't played once since the Sony monopoly began, which was why this, as one of Square-Enix's cross platform (initially Xbox 360 exclusive) JRPGs was so enticing. I longed to see what they had in store for me. HIronobu Sakaguchi was gone, but I had Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon, both excellent if not old fashioned games. Sadly, Last Remnant (Last? What is it about JRPGs from this pedigree exhausting the same thesaurus entry?) ran terribly on console. It's release on PC has greatly alleviated these problems, but alas, something about the game leaves me cold. It plays great and has a unique combat and character system, yet ,,, the last remnant of what I onced loved about the genre has dried up. Next stop, Xenoblade and Last Story (there we go again!) for Wii. Here I come.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game and stand by it. I have put probably about 300-400 hours into this game (not on steam, but mostly on xbox). I bought it on PC because it is a superior version which does allow more specific choices for characters and doesn't punish you for grinding.
I Think the battle system and character progression system is great, but not for everybpdy. Your characters will grow depending on the commands you give in battle, the commands you get to choose from in battle are limited, but are always swayed by the choices you have made for that group of characters previously. Instead of having 6 focused characters, which you make specific choices for growth, like in the usual JRPG fare, you have 20 characters and make general choices in combat that indirectly affect the character's growth. It means that all the choices you make will have an impact, so you have to be mindful of what abilities you want a group to have.
The battles are both challenging and engaging and unlike other JRPGs I've played. The fact they are large scale is really enjoyable, and you can also speed past them if you'd like. If you really want to enjoy it, you will need to use the wiki for it. There are details which appear as random in this game, but are really a number of complex factors that create a coherent, if unclear, system.
The game's content is mostly sidequests and completely optional, and are amongst the most rewarding challenges I have faced in most JRPGs. I always feel like there is more I could do and more progression I could make, creating powerful and interesting combinations of characters.
I thik this title is greatly misunderstood and underrated because of the sub-par Xbox release, but is really a unique JRPG gem and will shine through if you have the time and interest.

reviewText:
ok so i know little about JRPGs and only have a few hours but what i do know is so far its just FF sub plot missing girl boy goes to find girl,that being said its still a good story and game combat is well done but limited the squad bases give it a one up makes you think which i for one like.

Only one big CON that sticks out is YOU HAVE TO SAVE EVERY 10mins or if you get to a new part in the story cuz if you die with out saving your ♥♥♥♥ and have to do it all over and back at your last save. there are no auto saves this may be a jrpg thing i dont know but when i end up some where i was 1hr earlyer i just stop playing kills the mood have to replay everything all over, it is a some what chilled game i dont feel rushed when playing i can just play killing monsters does feel good charcters you meet are kinda tranparint not really much to them thou im saying this with  my time played.

in all its still a great game if have a the skill and temperment its for you even with the save thing i still want to play and that means some thing its worth the price and is cheap right now just play it and see if you like it even with the sale its easy on your wallet this my not be the best reveiw but i hope it helps in some way ill edit this as i play to help with any unsertenties.

reviewText: The Last Remnant is one of those JRPG's you will never forget. How come? Because that turn-base combat is enough to rip your hair out in frustration, and that you'd need therapy when the credits roll. Also, them side-quests. So many of them. It has many faults, but this is one of the games I genuinely love and wished that it has a bigger fanbase (AND A SEQUEL).\n\nPro-tip: never play it on hard-mode on your first playthrough. You'd shoot yourself in the face.

reviewText: One of the best japanese rpgs games so far on next gen consoles, and maybe the best one with a pc adaptation. Why you don't know it? The xbox version was laggy as hell because of the engine. On pc it's just smooth, esthetic and the universe is still a bit childish but the storyline and chara design are very original. The gameplay is unique and very dynamic as well, the difficulty is not overwhelming but really supperior(when you compare the game to the others of the genre)

reviewText: This game is confusing at first. It's also difficult until you figure out what you're doing. The voice acting can be terrible, and it took awhile to get into the story. At the current price of two and a half bucks though it's totally worth it. The combat system is neat when you figure it out and it plays like a game of chess only you have a partner that you can't control their moves. It's not for everyone, but for such a low price it's worth giving it a shot and looking past the flaws.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I've seen a lot of dislike for this game, but in my opinion it was a pretty fantastic game. The Last Remnant had a great story line, and a unique and interested battle system. The idea of squads instead of individual units is something that added the feel of actually controlling a small force instead of just a party of adventurers. And the morale system, while tricky and can work against you, led to shifts in battle in the same way they might happen in real life. Overall it was a lot of fun to play, even if the PC version was harder than the Xbox hard version.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is fairly linear, but has an environment immersive enough to keep interest.
The game get difficult rather quickly and it cannot be easily fixed by grinding, so a level of strategy and knowledge of game mechanics are best to succeed.

There are many unique and you can get attached to your favorites easily and so many sidequests, you feel that you must be a completionist before finishing the storyline.

It was worth the many hours playing.
